metadata.text: Achieve a smooth backside 360 by initiating with a carve on your heels, maintaining light pressure for balance.
metadata.videoTitle: Backside 360s Fully Explained!

metadata.text: **Master the backside 360 by focusing on a smooth setup carve with light heel pressure, a controlled wind-up on your toe edge, and a committed upper body rotation, using counter-rotation to fine-tune your spin and landing.**
metadata.videoTitle: Backside 360s Fully Explained!

metadata.text: Execute the spin with a dedicated upper body rotation, initiating the turn while keeping your shoulders aligned.
metadata.videoTitle: Backside 360s Fully Explained!

metadata.text: Commit fully to the rotation for a successful and stylish backside 360.
metadata.videoTitle: Backside 360s Fully Explained!

metadata.text: Build momentum by transitioning to your toe edge with a controlled wind-up, preparing for the rotation.
metadata.videoTitle: Backside 360s Fully Explained!

metadata.rawText: sure to practice and train riding in this strong stable position I'd recommend trying to ride down the mountain just holding this position for as long as you can seeing if you can go and do a straight line well stay in this position stack because that's what you'll be doing when going off of a jump When approaching a jump your goal is to ride off straight all the way from the bottom of the jump to the top of the
metadata.text: When approaching a jump, maintain a strong, stable riding position (stacked). Your goal is to ride straight off the jump, from the bottom to the top, without adjusting your stance.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Hit Your Jumps Snowboarding [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: The Sweet Spot of a landing all jumps have something called the knuckle the knuckle is the flat section after the lip of the takeoff it goes takeoff knuckle then landing and The Sweet Spot refers to the part of the landing that has the least amount of impact this is generally around 30% of the way down the jump past halfway down the landing you start getting into what we call going
metadata.text: Focus your landing on the "sweet spot" of the jump. This is the area about 30% of the way down the landing hill, where the impact will be the softest.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Hit Your Jumps Snowboarding [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: to hit the four key points your stacked body position a straight takeoff Edge pressure and timing both are the four main points you're trying to improve when doing this training exercise with those in place it's time to get spinning the first backside 360 you can do is just traversing across the slope to do this get on your tow Edge going along the
metadata.text: To learn a backside 360, focus on these four key points: stacked body position, straight takeoff, edge pressure, and timing. Start by traversing across the slope on your toe edge to get a feel for the rotation.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Backside 360 On A Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: to keep centered over your board a front side 360 doesn't take much power so you don't need to make this motion super exaggerated instead just focus on keeping stacked and aligned you want to avoid having your hips open towards the jump so by consciously going and shifting your shoulders closed and keeping stacked over your board you'll be in the ideal position to generate power on your front side free second you
metadata.text: To land a frontside 360, stay stacked and aligned over your board, focusing on keeping your shoulders closed rather than opening your hips towards the jump. This will help you maintain balance and generate the necessary power.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Frontside 360 On A Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: takeoff serves two purposes keeping your carve straight and letting you time your snap you want your aim to start looking away from the takeoff as your board starts to leave the lift of a jump setup cars are not very important on backside 180s so it become covering them more in depth in our backside 360 tutorial what is important is making sure you're maintaining your stack position and riding off a jump in a straight line a
metadata.text: Maintain your stacked position and ride off the jump in a straight line. As you leave the jump, start looking away from the takeoff to initiate the spin.
metadata.videoTitle: Master The Backside 180 On Your Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: Edge the harder it will be to hold your strong tall body position making it more likely you start to lean forward resulting in Breaking at the waist setup cars are one of the things you really want to get in place before going off the Jump a great way to practice this is just on the slope find a super mellow pitch slope VI a cat track or a green run and practice your setup car trying
metadata.text: Find a mellow slope (like a cat track or green run) and practice your setup carve. Maintaining a strong, tall body position will help you avoid leaning forward and breaking at the waist when you eventually hit the jump.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Backside 360 On A Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: counter rotation counter rotation is when you have your upper body rotate separately from your lower body and then you tighten your core bring everything back centered at the same time you stop your constant Rotation by counter rotating you slow down your constant speed of rotation and this is why using counter rotation should be saved into the end of your spins since it will be
metadata.text: To control your rotation at the end of a frontside 360, use counter-rotation: rotate your upper body in the opposite direction of your spin, and then center your core to stop the spin. This will help you slow down and land your trick.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Frontside 360 On A Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: dial in this rotation recap a slight setup carve switching to your heel Edge as you start going up the lip a closed off upper body opening up as you throw your spin a straight edge line as you leave the lip off your tail Bing the knuckle of the jump as you bring your legs up locking in your spot and rotating around it putting down the landing in a blind landing position
metadata.text: As you approach the jump, initiate a slight heel-edge carve, then open your upper body as you throw your spin, bringing your legs up to spot the landing as you rotate.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Frontside 360 On A Snowboard [Tips Only]

metadata.rawText: rotated behind you and have your hips slightly turned towards your tail this is what's called wind up and it's how you generate rotation on a front side spin a common mistake on front spins is opening your body towards the takeoff this opened hip position limits your range of motion making it harder to generate your spins it also shifts your weight onto your heels making it harder

metadata.fullText: In this video, we're going to go over the most important head positioning techniques that you need to have unlocked for trampolining and landing on a snowboard. For those of you that don't know, when you're rotating a trick, you're trying to keep your eyes at the knuckle of the jump. And if you're going and landing blind going up to the jump, you want to land looking back uphill at that knuckle. And if you're doing something like a backside 360, you want to have your vision go and pull all the way past that. But on a trampoline, we're not traveling forward. So that means our vision is going to be set right in the center of us. So pick the center of the trampoline. That's the knuckle of the jump. And I'm actually going to be holding my head in that position for all my tricks. So if I do like a seven, see how my head's locked in that one position, and it's not moving around. This is the key to fluid spins on your snowboard and on the trampoline. and that is minimizing the head position. When we're doing tricks, we're not trying to go and throw our head into them. Instead, we're trying to keep our head as stationary as possible.

If you go and hit something with sideways momentum, that momentum is going to carry you all the way off. This is why it's really important to take as straight of an angle as you can into the feature. Because by keeping a straight angle, you're going to minimize your sideways momentum. There's things you can do to stop your momentum, like catching the rail, landing angled, but by limiting your angled approach, it's going to make it so you have to do way less to kill that momentum, making it way easier to lock in and slide to the end of any feature. Whenever you're riding the park, you want to maintain a little bit of bend in your legs and a little bit of forward lean in your upper body. This keeps you balanced and in control and lets you go pop up, get wild with it, have fun with it. So, every time you're in the park riding, try to keep yourself a little bit bent, a little bit lean forward, because I'm telling you, it's going to make a world of difference. Because if you go ride too tall, too straight, you're going to be flatfaced, unbalanced, susceptible to falling. But as you go and keep that little bit of hinge, little bit of bend, even as you pull from keeping that little bit of bend, that's how you get control. That's how you get style. But because I was treating my switch front side like I was treating my backside spins, I was going and leading with that upper body, shifting all the way over into this position was letting me over rotate and throw downward over my nose with my tail for a backside rotation. So I was trying to fix that by like how could I do it? That's when I started thinking about foot pedaling.
metadata.text: **Initiate frontside spins by leading with your hips, then chest, and finally arms, to avoid over-rotation and nose dives.**

metadata.fullText: But if you're riding and you generally ride in a tall position, relying on leaning, this leaning posture isn't going to be good for jumping. If I'm coming off a jump straight like this, and I try to go and bring my legs up, look at how that's stopping me. But watch what happens when I add a slight bit of hinge in my upper body. Now I can bring my legs up all here. And this is a pivot point. If I'm straight back as I squat down, I'm not going to be able to reposition. I'm falling. I'm stiff. If I'm going overextended, I'm straight over my board. I can't bring up those legs. But by letting the chest come forward in correlation to the hips going back, we have a full spectrum of movement where as I drop down, I'm dropping down more and more to my knees.
metadata.text: **For better jumping, hinge your upper body forward slightly as you squat down, creating a pivot point that allows for easier leg tucks and repositioning.**

metadata.fullText: There's no amount of force you should be using. Instead, jumping comes from simplifying your motions, preemptively setting up your body so you can use as little extension and as little extra power and snap as possible. Because power and height on a snowboard doesn't come from your legs. Instead, it comes from seamlessly shifting your weight back and forth and channeling your energy through. So, if you go and think about trying to do an ollie or a jump, you're missing the whole point. And there's multiple spectrums that we want to be on for a backside 540. This is a very flexible trick because we can use counter rotation. And you can see I'm dropping my upper body. My weight is extremely shifted towards that back leg.
metadata.text: **Focus on fluid weight shifts and controlled counter-rotation rather than raw leg power to maximize jump height and execute tricks like a backside 540.**

So, he wants to keep the balance as similar to that as possible. He's doing this by making sure that his chin is tucked into his core. This keeps a little bit of tension here, a little bit of bend in the legs, and that's going to keep him balanced and make it so as he rotates, he comes back into that balance point.

metadata.fullText: But go do the push test, get someone to push you, do your hops, see which foot you slightly favor. You will find your correct foot given time. So don't worry about it too much and just try to go and start off with that little bit of information. The most important thing to figure out is the width of stance that works best for you. But the principle to base your stance around is the stack position. Snowboarding is based around the stack position where your weight set over the balls of your feet. That's where you'd like jump off your toes. And the reason why it's based off that is because it holds a little bit of edge pressure, gives you cruise. So you want to stance that lets you hold this position naturally and comfortably. So if we go too narrow and try to do that, it's going to make it so as we squat down, our knees come in and we're not able to get fully out. If we go too wide, we're not going to be able to stand fully straight. And when we stand down, our knees are going bowy out. So, we're trying to find that stand foot that goes and lets us come down and have our knees go down in an even keel. And generally, you can use a forehand trick for this. So, like that's a narrow stance, that's a long stance, that's a mediumly wide stance, and then anywhere between this zone is usually pretty good. Reference on your board is going to be pretty good for you. So, play around with it. Find your comfortable range of motion and play around with your snowboard. Find that position that you feel like you could hold all day while going and jumping off the balls of your feet. The main reason you want more angles on your bindings is so you have more rotation to open your hips. And the main downside is it's going to put more wear and tear in your knees, more wear and tear on your ankles and make it so you have to ride in this more committed position. So the more squared off and straight you have your feet pointed, the more relaxed neutral you want. Too straight, you're going to be too neutral. So having a little bit of shift is going to go and give you the benefits of being able to open your hips. So like turning, it's really important to open your tips and it's going to let you go and maintain a steady position that's not going to put wear and tear on your joints. A great way to go and feel your stance is to go get the general sense of where it's at and just to do a little hops hops into your position and trying to get a range of motion where you feel like you can fully extend, come down and catch yourself in that zone. It's really going to depend on what you like personally. Wider stance, you're going to land more. More narrow stance, you're going to have more range of motion and faster whipping. Somewhere in the middle is going to be good for pretty much everything. My recommendation is the four-bolt system. It has less adjustability on how wide you can make your stand and how narrow you can make it, but it more than makes up for it with being able to secure your bindings on and not need to deal with them getting loose and slipping. What's a super common problem with ESTs when you're going and putting on your bindings, you have this thing here, and this determines the angle that your bindings will be angled at. How it works is it starts baseline 0 0 and you want to rotate it until it's on the angle you want. So here if I'm setting up a board posy pausy I put it on 18 and that's going to make it so the four bolts sync up on the angle that it's set on. And this is a really important part of getting the bindings on because if you don't go and put the bindings on the right angle for what you're trying to do, you're not going to be able to get the bolts to line up. So, I go and get it slightly tight on each one of the four screws and then go and rotate in a circle getting it tighter and tighter.

If I go and snap my upper body too soon, it's going to disconnect me and make it so I don't have that strength in the core. That's why it's so crucial to not go and overextend. If you go and throw your upper body past this 45° angle here, it's going to take too much core strength to try to pull everything back align. metadata.text: **Coordinate your upper body's snap with your leg pop for optimal rotation; avoid over-extending or leading with your upper body to maintain core strength and maximize rotational speed.**

So keeping this hinge forward in the upper body is not only increasing range of motion, but it's also keeping your balance point set over the balls of your feet. And that's the key to getting these rotations. You want to go and have an upper body angle that lets you go and do a few things. First, it lets you go and hold your heel edge with minimal motion. So, here I'm leaning a little bit, but I'm squatting down quite a bit and pulling my upper body forward, letting me get this heel edge angle with minimum leaning. Because if you're leaning on your heel edge, you'll have to lean just as much on your toe edge in order to rebalance. And then I'm maintaining this angle on the toe edge while opening up. Never trying to open so far that I get straight over top of my board because that's going to make it so I no longer have my chest over my knees. And then this position right here is the perfect position for me because it lets me go and snap my spin all the way through on the same plane. So see how my upper body is rotating through the same direction the whole way. So even though it's crouched down and the froze seems a little bit down, because it's continuing on an even path, it's going to flow really naturally into a really solid spin. metadata.fullText: So what I was trying to tell Ben to do here is to add more bend to his legs to get it more bent in. This was a little bit hard to implement because he was very confused on just how bent down you're really supposed to get yourself and how squatted into a position you want to be and how early on. The coaching technique that I used to help this sink in for him is I told him to think of like a Japanese euro carver, how they get really down low onto their edge in order to go and get those deep, deep turns. You actually want to be doing the same thing on your setup carve initially for the heel edge. Trying to sink all the way down. The reason why is the more you sink down and the more you squat down, the more heel edge pressure you can put in without needing to rely on leaning. And that was one of the big problems we had with Ben because of his posture is he was needing to rely on leaning his whole body in order to hold that edge pressure that he needed. So it' make it so he had to lean to his heels, lean to his toes. And because he wasn't adding enough bend to his legs, he was staying straight using that little bit of lean. And that's making it so it's too flat base to grip in an edge and actually dig in. And if you can't dig in your edge, you're going to get this little bit of slip. So here we just spent the day working on that. And I just spent every time like Ben more down, more squatted. And we can start seeing that he's doing it better here.
metadata.text: **Squat deeply into your turns to create more edge pressure through leg bend, mimicking a low carver, rather than relying on leaning your whole body.**

So his arms are snapping relatively slow and he's relying on pulling with his core and pulling with his hips. That's a really important thing for this. You need to make sure that your hips are the primary place you're getting power. And then you want to make sure you're driving it all the way overextending as much as you can.

metadata.fullText: And I do this also before every double back 10. I close my eyes and just think like, okay, snap, pull, snap, pull. So, it's really something that's helped me a lot is getting that motion of feeling that motion, feeling that snap, then closing my eyes and trying to add that feeling into the trick. Uh, for the cab 9, when I went and tossed it, I went and popped it. And then as I pulled my head into that position, that's very similar to the dubback 10. I then felt that comfort and it then I could see the landing. And from there I was able to trust because I already felt out that process. And now let's talk a little bit of how we can deal with this fear and how much fear is too much. Because even though we'll all have that little bit of anxiety, that tight chest, that like bit of doubt in the mind, it's really important to know how much of it's reasonable and how much of it's unnecessary. So, what I like to do or this is set a couple rules and go and try to simplify tricks into the most basic principles possible. So, the first rule if I'm doing something like a dub back 10, I have a rule that I have to do two perfect back sevens in a row before trying it. Because the thing I'm worried about the most on a dub back 10 is that I'll go and mess up my takeoff, not get the rotation, and I'll go and land on my head or I'll go and hit the knuckle. But if I do two perfect back sevens landing in the sweet spot and I'm taking the same speed every time, I'm able to go and be like, "Okay, you don't need to worry about completely botching the takeoff, and you don't need to worry about knuckling the jump, and you don't need to worry about having the right amount of power." So, by going and doing the prior tricks and getting them perfect with the two in the row, I'm able to be like, "Okay, brain, don't worry about that stuff. You have that stuff. Let's go and worry about the things that are unique to this trick." And that's really one of the biggest keys to going and getting comfortable with tricks is narrowing it down so you can focus on the unique aspects of each trick. For example, if we're doing like a backside 270 onto a rail, we're going to be like, "Okay, I need to get a good takeoff so I can get over the rail and rotate so I can land in my board slide." So, you need to really think about that takeoff because it's the most important part. Then, if you want to do a back to pullback, there's a little bit more complexity. So, I can't spend my whole time thinking about that takeoff getting over because I need to be thinking about that counter rotation so I can then go and pull it back. So, that's what I'm talking about by like going and simplifying a trick. So, if you're really comfortable with like backside 360s, think about what part of the backside 360s work for you, what parts are easy for you and then what parts you're worried about changing for the five. And then another thing that really helps is making sure that you're just not overdoing it. If you're going and feeling sketchy about your prior tricks before trying the bigger ones, don't try the bigger ones. It's not worth it. Take the time, learn the fundamentals. Build that base because the fear is there to protect you. And working past it is part of being a great snowboarder, part of learning, part of progressing, and why snowboarding is so fun. But sometimes it's there for a good reason. For example, say I'm going to a rail and I want to do a backside boardside. I really want to do a backside boardside on this rail. What parts of this trick are scaring me? Okay, I'm scared that I'm going to land on the rail, slip out, and fall on my back. Very fair concern.
metadata.text: Simplify complex tricks by mastering prerequisite movements and focusing on the unique challenges of the new trick, rather than worrying about fundamental skills you've already perfected.

So when you're going and doing your carving, you're going and doing your turning, remember these preemptive motions work. You need to set them. metadata.fullText: So, the solution for this and the answer to riding the side hit is going to be a few things. First, let's break down the in run. Instead of going straight and then trying to turn into it, I'm preemptively setting my whole body on the angle of the takeoff. So, my board's angled towards the takeoff, my hips angled towards the takeoff, my upper body's angled towards the takeoff. This is making it so it's like I'm riding just straight downhill even though it's off the track. And this is minimizing the motions because we want to maintain a pretty flat base position. You obviously need a bit of toe edge to go and turn up here and grip into the snow, but we don't want to actually be getting on that edge and riding it because that's going to be a harder position to generate power from. And if we look at the takeoff, you can see that I'm leaving relatively flat base and I'm keeping myself as centered over my board as I can. And this is actually a cool little thing is you can have a little bit of toe pressure, but as you go and extend your legs, it's going to make it so you're less hunched over because now your body's taller. And when you do this, you want to lessen the pressure on the base of your snowboard. So even if you have a lot of toe edge coming into the feature because you need it to hit the feature, as you go and extend and pop up, we want to lessen that toe edge to take off as flat base as possible.
metadata.text: **Pre-angle your entire body (board, hips, upper body) towards the side hit takeoff, then extend your legs and reduce toe edge pressure just before takeoff to launch from a flat base.**

metadata.fullText: Because if you land toeheavy in this situation, like say I landed completely over my toes here, I'd dig in and I'd get bucked. So I'm actually making sure to under rotate slightly be dig in my heels to absorb that little bit of rotational energy coming into the landing. Because even with this impact, notice how my board wants to keep spinning throughout that landing and it keeps shifting. So ideally, we're rotating these tricks early enough so that way we can use counter rotation to slow down. But when you need to go and speed up the rotation throughout the full duration, we're going to need to under rotate slightly because if I landed with my board completely rotated here, that little bit of slip out would have caused me to slip towards my toe edge and that' make it so I didn't land the trick. So here I'm purposely under rotating and jamming my heels in to kill that rotational energy. And the really cool thing about these landing mechanics is they're basically exactly the same as proper jumping mechanics. The only difference is instead of loading up to explode and generate power using the same principles to go and slow down, elongate your motions and absorb that energy. It's also exactly how you want to be landing in powder. here. If it was deeper snow, I'd just have my hips slightly more tilted up, upper body more pulled forward, and that way I could land tail heavy. Because it's not very deep, I can go and use my hip shift to go and pull my board down and only land a little bit tail heavy. The only thing that really stops this technique from working is over elongation. If we lose that hinge in our hips, we're going to go and slip out towards our heels. Here, it's happening for a few reasons.
metadata.text: To land a spinning trick, slightly under-rotate and dig your heels in to absorb rotational energy, preventing toe-edge catches.

I decided to end the day with a few cab under flips. I did one, it felt easy. I may not have a brain, gentlemen, but I have an idea. Then it clicked. I can do this double. I haven't tried a new double in over 5 years, so the idea made me sick. But when I decide I'm going to do something, I do it. I strapped in, put my head down, and dropped in. It worked exactly how I imagined. I could see the whole time I was in complete control. All those fears vanished. What was left was the simple truth. My mental work, it's been working. With that, I went home to rest because next time I'd be riding the largest bag possible. Day five, the beast. This bag is massive. 3 seconds of air time minimum. It's by far the biggest jump I've ever hit, larger than anything in Canada. My expectations were low. I had one more day of riding after this, so I figured I'd do a bunch of straight airs, but I couldn't even figure out how to drop in. The platform was so steep and gnarly. You have to sidelit from the start or you'll overshoot. Then I hit the jump and it was perfect. Smooth, massive, controlled. Nailed my edge to edge pop and it was smooth. Next 720. Even easier than the 360. Double back 10. Got it. Hard snap.

metadata.fullText:
This is going to be a little bonus section just on 
the importance of good form and how you actually want to use this position to load powerful because 
it's going to make things so much easier. So, first of all, I want to say this form is what 
I use for pretty much everything. jumping, it naturally sets you up. Carving, it lets 
you get you lower and it's just going to be a really powerful building block that will actually 
take you to the next level of snowboarding. It's flexible and best done with other movements, but 
woohoo, it's really what you want to think about and ground yourself over. A lot of people think 
that this is the strong position, squared in the board, and when I squat, I keep my chest up and 
squat down, but this is going to make me fall back because it relies on leaning. And when it's 
icy, we really don't want to be leaning. There's actually three motions that go into doing a proper 
low down squat position that will let you utilize your turn. First is a little bit of opening of 
the hips. When we're squared, it's going to be restricted and it's going to be tough to expand 
our body. But as soon as we open our hips a bit, it now lets us drop our weight. We'll stay 
in more over top of our snowboard. The next part is instead of keeping the spine straight, 
what's going to make it so as we squat down, our weight shifts more and more to the heels, 
what will make us lean. Instead, we want to have our hips back and a little bit of hinge forward. 
So that way now when we squat down, we're really loading our weight onto it. And then the last 
thing is doing all these motions in correlation.
metadata.text: To achieve a powerful snowboarding stance, open your hips, hinge your hips back while leaning your torso slightly forward (not keeping your spine straight), and coordinate these movements to load your weight effectively over the board.

I'm sure you noticed my back steps are a little bit offaxis and a little bit cked. This isn't coming because I'm really doing anything particular. Instead, it's because I'm getting such a strong pop up and a strong snap that I'm able to go and change my axis rotation for upper rotation just by dipping the head.

metadata.fullText: And that's something he's doing on every one of these features. Notice how his legs are coming down and meeting the landing in the transition. What meaning the landing does means that you're going to be countering a lot of the G force that's coming as you hit impact. That's going to let you get stronger legs and be more powerful going through. Anytime you're landing a jump, you want to be taking your legs and extending it and meeting that landing to help absorb the impact. A really important note is look at how his legs are still bent. If you fully extend your legs to meet that landing, it's going to fully extend your body. That's going to shift your weight to your heel edge, make it so you don't have that strong balance point in the core. So when you try to absorb the force, it's going to pull you really heavy onto that heels and you're sort of going to collapse. But by maintaining this hinge in the hips, bend the legs, even as you're extending to meet the landing, you can now go and exaggerate this position. So for his more G's, he can put the hips further back as he squats down and pull the upper body more forward in correlation. All to maintain that same balance point.
metadata.text: **Land transitions with bent knees and a hinged hip to absorb impact and maintain a balanced, powerful stance.**

and that is preemptive motion the reason inexperienced Riders are harder to predict is because they don't set preemptive movements to demonstrate this I'll give you two examples on the left is swapping from tow Edge to heel Edge without preemptive setup on the right with preet up with without preset up the back tail slides out and with prese setup the transition is smooth this loss of traction is caused by three things first the board is slightly angled to the tow Edge this makes it so the tail of a snowboard needs to travel more distance from the nose of a snowboard giving it more sideways momentum second is trying to move into the heel side body position all at once shifting momentum works the same way as slowing down the faster you do it the more gForce it will put on your body this leads to the fur issue causing the board to scuff across the snow turning on a snowboard works a lot like turning on a car as you hit a corner you begin to drift if a turn happens too fast for the amount of traction you have so if your momentum is greater than the traction the tires will skid that's exactly what's happening on this turn I do three pre motions to counter this first a slight shift to flat base this increases the size of a turn radius reducing sideways momentum second opening my chest this has two purposes one it makes it so you can see where you're going before you go there second it starts your rotation combine it with the third opening your hips while loading into your heel side stack position this motion will slightly turn your board finishing in a slightly pointed heelside position with slight Edge pressure and from there I can push weight into my heel Edge allowing me to get a clean heelside turn and then I repeat this on every turn fast Turns Slow turns every turn I'm following these steps at different speeds and it's this linking of turns that gives the feeling and look of flow from this base you can start to play with it hyper exaggerate opening your hips narrowing your turn radius so you can perform super fast turn then you can increase your Edge pressure in order to get lower to the snow every time you see someone linking a sck park trick or linking a dope turn down the mountain it's because we're using pre motions and we're just going and adding different steps or taking steps out depending on what they're doing when doing something like a toide slash I do a few preemptive set positions first I'm making sure my board is angled towards where I want to slash next I'm loading my weight into my stack position putting a slight pressure onto my tow Edge once I go and finish my acceleration I start to unweight it I do this by going in extending my legs what goes and puts less pressure onto my tow Edge more pressure flat base as I extend my legs I shift my weight slightly to my front foot this removes the weight on my back foot allowing me to do the next step activating my upper body in a premotion in order to initiate counter rotation from there I go and shift my weight over to my heels and enter my heelside slide slip position and I enter it and push as much as I need to in order to slow down and hit the slash I'm looking to hit snowb works by combining all these pre motions with a specific motion to set your trick a lot of these pre motions are the same for any similar setup but there are slight differences and new motions that you'll need to learn missing a crucial premotion is like missing the last piece to a puzzle find it and you're riding will be complete let me know if you like videos like this one and we'll be back at it with another video soon
metadata.text: **Use preemptive movements like shifting to a flat base, opening your chest, and opening your hips before initiating a turn to ensure smooth transitions and prevent loss of traction.**

metadata.fullText: Picking the right pair of boots is one of the most important things you can do as a snowboarder to the extent where if you pick the wrong pair of boots, it can affect your whole season. One time I was riding the wrong boots and it gave me a bone spur that made it so I actually couldn't ride for multiple weeks at a time and it actively made it one of the most painful years of my life. So fitting and picking the perfect pair of boots is one of the most important things you can do. And in this video, I'm going to walk you through everything I learned about picking boots over the last 18 years. And I've learned a lot of cool tricks and techniques for selecting the perfect pair because I got some wonky looking feet. And yeah, we're going to break this video down into five parts and that will make it easier for a specific section because we're going to be covering a lot of information, giving you everything you need in order to go and make the boot choice that'll let you ride all day with no pain. So, let's get right into it. First thing you want to do when picking a pair of boots is make sure that you have a general sense of the size of your foot. Every boot fitting shop will have these tools. And usually there's also boot fitters that will help you do it. And a really important thing to note for this is every board company's boots are going to fit slightly differently. So here I'm measuring at a 8.5. It's also really important to measure the other foot because you can have two different size feet. 8.5 here. That doesn't necessarily mean that I'll be using an 8.5 boot. For example, I ordered a pair of 32s at 8.5 and they were far too short to the extent that riding them caused me permanent nail damage and I just could not punch in the toes. So, that's why we're going to go really in depth into the fitting and how they should feel for length and width. Cuz that's the other part about snowboard boots is the width of your foot. And you can see that you can measure it. And the most important thing for this is each boot model is coming in a different width. And some boots actually come in a wide form and just a normal form. I have really wide feet. So you can see that my feet at the balls of the feet really come and spread out here. This means I'm going to need a really wide shoe. And this really narrows down the amount of boots that I'll be able to get. So you really want to be mindful when you're picking your boots. Is your foot wider? Is your foot more narrow? Uh generally if you have issues with just putting on normal shoes, it feels tight. you probably have a bit of a wider foot where if you can just buy like any pair of Nikes off the shelves and they feel great uh whip rise then your foot's probably more on the normal side because every brand fits so differently it's really important to not be brand loyal or just buy a boots without trying it on anything like reviews it all depends on your personal experience and how that boot fits specifically for your foot because it's not just about size here let's go and find a boot to go and try we will try on this DC 9.5. So, a full size larger than what I normally ride. And this is just going to help me go and tell you what to look for for too large of a boot. So, whenever you're trying on a boot, it's important to do the full tightening process. I have skinny calves, so I always need to do this part extra tight.

metadata.fullText: This is a stack position. All the way down to here, I'm still maintaining a stack position. And this also is true for opening the hips. I can go and maintain the same center of balance with opening my hips, dropping down, and shifting all within it. Basically, every single movement and every single thing you do, you want to try and maintain your balance over the same point. And that's how you go and get power and control in snowboarding. I'll go and give you a little freestyle example here. If I'm doing something like a front side 180 and I pop off flat base, it's going to make it so as I rotate, I'm going to land very heel heavy and risk falling. but by just by maintaining my weight over my balls of my feet, I go and rotate through and I land back on the balls of my feet. So, every time you go and do a turn or anything like that, you're trying to move within a range of motion that lets you keep that center of balance. Obviously, if you switch your heel edge, you'll need to go and switch your weight to your heels slightly, but we're still trying to keep that weight set over top of a board. So, in this video, we're just going to walk through how you can go and get comfortable with this motion, find it, and how you can go and reach the limits of what it can do for you. And that's going to let you go and perform way better maneuvers on your snowboard. So, first thing I want you to do is find your neutral stack position. It always needs to have a little bit of bend in your legs. If your legs are completely straight, your weight's going to be set balanced over top of your feet. So, straight feet, no go. Bend down. Feel how she goes. And try to add enough bend that you're feeling that balance point. You don't want to have too much bend to hit this point because we're not going to be able to ride all day like this. It's going to be too intense of a motion. So, the base of your stack position should be the bare minimum bend in your body in order to have this balance on the balls of your feet. The next thing that's really important is you need to make sure that your upper body comes down in correlation to the bend in your legs.
metadata.text: Maintain a "stack position" with a slight bend in your legs and upper body, keeping your weight balanced over the balls of your feet to maximize control and power in all snowboarding movements.

metadata.fullText: Hey shredders, it's my birthday today, so I figured it'd be a perfect opportunity to go and show you my five favorite exercises that I do as much as possible even on my birthday. These exercises help build your foundation as a snowboarder while increasing your range of motion that's going to give you way more power. Very simple motions, very delicate, but the benefit they have to learning how to move your body and controlling if you're in your healthy range is really hard to even comprehend because it's just so useful. So, the first thing I do is I think it's called good mornings. And these are just really great because snowboarding uses a lot of hip, a lot of lower back, and a lot of hinging and like pulling through. So, it's really good to go and get those muscles activated and strong. So, for this, all you want to do is put your front foot forward, a little bit angled in towards the left, not much, but slight. Then, you want to take your back foot and put around 10% weight on it, having your toes. Your stance should be pretty close like this. And this is where the motion is a little bit complex and a little bit nuanced. You want to go suck in your ribs, get completely tall and extended, and then just tilt your hips back, pulling your hips up into the air. And you should feel a pretty intense burn in your left side of your glute all the way through. And then we want to try flex it and pull it back up.
metadata.text: **Strengthen your hips and lower back with "good mornings":** Stand with your front foot angled slightly in, back foot at 10% weight, then hinge at your hips while keeping your torso tall and extending your glute to feel a burn.

going to save you so many Falls and so much pain there's a big misconception where power comes from snowboarding a lot of people think the harder you snap power you get but if you snap too soon delay it it's going to thr up your takeoff throw up your control of the landing and just hurt everything and that's why power on jumps doesn't come from a fast snap motion instead it comes from smoothness and consistency you'll get way more power off the lip of a jump by maintaining the same controlled upper body rotation speed then you will growing fast and then slowing it down because if you snap too fast and need to delay that motion you're stopping your rotational momentum and that's delaying all the benefits you're getting from going and trying to go and snap harder making the rotation harder while giving you less control so whenever you're going and doing a spin instead of thinking about throwing hard think about throwing smooth and maintaining your upper body momentum as long as you can the larger your backside spin the more you can lead up your upper body something on back one you're hardly leading at all a backside 360 a little bit more backside 540 a little bit more and on something like a backside 7 you're rotating your upper body as much as you can off the lift leading the rotation so your upper body will be rotated around 180 and this is because it takes time for your legs to catch up so if you over snap like a backside 360 you're not going to have any trick left by the time your legs catch up but on back seven you have that room and you're aiming to grab at 270 so the bigger your backside spin the more you can lead with your upper body when spinning it's really important to be patient and wait to grab your spins pop up get the full rotation then grab so coming up rotating then grabbing and that's going to give you so much more control so even there where I got a bad takeoff got a bad snap because I waited to go and grab the spin it let me go and give that little bit of extra rotation and pull into it so whenever you're going and doing a spin and you want to add a grab remember set your spin throw it and once you're in the air and feeling in control then you grab by doing this you'll get so much more control and your jumps will be way more stylish for it when doing something like a backside board slide we don't want to start straight and then try to enter our backside board side position instead we want to PR UL have our body in a backside board side position so then we can just counter rotate so we're coming in preemptively positioning our body and this is letting us get that nice bit of control whenever you're doing a board slide maintain a nice stack position because that's going to give you so much more power we don't want to go from a tall position into a board slide position instead we want to hold our board slide position and going just counter rotate into that board slide this will go in limit the Motions you need to do and let you keep your Center balance set on the same point making board slides way easier every time you hit a rail or a box you're going to be jumping sideways onto it and if you go sideways onto a rail it's going to create something called sideways momentum and to stop sideways momentum we do something called hitting the rail angled so this is hitting the rail slightly from the side to kill that momentum not very noticeable on a 50/50 but on something like the backside board slide it's way more noticeable so I'm coming in hitting the side of a rail and this is letting me kill that momentum so even can like over St there as then walk in come in hit the side come down by going and hitting the side of the rail it stops your sideways momentum and lets you go and fully control the feature if you don't do this you're just going to slide off the far side and it's not going to let you lock in so every time you're doing a board side 50/50 even if it's subtle make you're hitting the rail slightly angled towards the side that you're taking off from

more velocity and that way you can hold more traction and get lower to the snow without needing to worry about falling over over and that's how you can start connecting it building power and what we really want to see out of these turns is for them to go like this speeding up speeding up then as you lighten up slowing down slowing down getting on your back tow Edge speeding up speeding up accelerating right at the point where you're trying to hit your maximum turn so final recap all you need to do is first keep your weight more centered over your board next don't go and extend your chest so high and don't fully straighten out your legs you can do this by keeping a little bit Bend more Bend in them or just extending less and lastly don't go and start loading pressure on that edge until you're on your toe Edge make sure that your toe Edge is set in place before you start squatting down into it because this is not fully utilizing the power you have as a rider so make these changes and I think it's going to make your carving way more explosive way more fun and should let you get way lower turns let me know how it goes and let me know if you need any more feedback for anyone watching this video you can get feedback just like this on addiction plus enjoy and happy shredding
metadata.text: Shift your weight towards the back of your board, maintain a bent stance without fully extending your legs, and only apply pressure to your edge once it's engaged.
metadata.videoTitle: Unlock More Powerful Carves

metadata.text: Use hip rotation, core engagement, and full hip extension to generate power for backside spins, maximizing range of motion.
metadata.videoTitle: This Discovery Changed Backside Spins Forever

metadata.fullText: If you try to throw a front side spin all at once, it's going to be a really short movement. I do this on my cab where I'll come in and no matter how patient I am, because I'm throwing everything at once, I always end up in this overthrowing position. So, that's why we really want to take this offseason time to go and practice moving these body parts independently. So, I come up my snowboard stance, balls of the feet. Oh, and this is actually really cool and really help my front side spins. I'm preemptively setting my weight where I want on my heel edge. So, toe edge, heel edge. See how small of a motion that is? This makes it so I can just go straight from toe edge, very little movement into my heel edge. And when I'm doing that, I'm pulling my arms back a little bit. So, just pulling here, not so much that we're starting to close or this knee is coming forward like this because you're not going to be able to generate that much power, but just enough where your right hand is sort of towards your back leg here. And then I want you to practice going and moving the hips, moving the torso, moving the chest, finishing with the arms in this tall position. So it looks like this.
metadata.text: Practice rotating your hips, torso, and chest before your arms to create a smoother, more powerful frontside spin.
metadata.videoTitle: 5 Snowboard Exercises I Do Every Day — Here's Why

metadata.text: Focus on shifting your hips to generate power and maintain control throughout the jump.
metadata.videoTitle: I Made These Mistakes So You Don’t Have To! - EP 3

metadata.fullText: And that is you want to have your toe edge position as similar to your heel edge position as possible. So, watch what happens when I fast forward here.
metadata.text: Maintain a balanced stance by keeping your toe and heel edge positions as symmetrical as possible.
metadata.videoTitle: Breaking Down Pro Snowboard Spins – What I’m Missing (29-Minute Study)

metadata.text: To generate maximum pop, drive weight into your snowboard's tail as you leave the jump's lip.
metadata.videoTitle: Park Jumps Made Easy!

metadata.text: Focus on a strong pop off the takeoff for initial spin and rotation.
metadata.videoTitle: Improving Your Frontside 360s!

metadata.text: Maintain a tall, stacked body position with minimal leg bend when launching off jumps to achieve a more stable straight air.
metadata.videoTitle: You are probably Bending Your Legs Too Much when jumping

metadata.text: Prioritize a straight air for improved control and stability when launching off jumps.
metadata.videoTitle: You are probably Bending Your Legs Too Much when jumping

metadata.fullText: That's going to give us full vision and full control. So, in this video, let's go over how you can learn that. So, the first thing that we're going to need to make sure we have locked in is our position. We covered in the last video, but it's worth talking about because it's so important. If we're too straight and tall, it's going to be impossible to clear our spot over at that point. And that's going to make it so people are going to be tempted to go and lean forward or rounding the spine. You really don't want to be rounding the spine or hinging at the hips because when you go and bounce, your weight's going to be very set over your toes and it's going to really compromise your back. So, the only way to keep our head in this position with being strong is to go have a little bit of bend in the legs, a little bit of hinge in the hips, and have your chin come down naturally.
metadata.text: **Maintain a strong, balanced stance with bent knees and a slight hip hinge, allowing your chin to naturally drop for optimal vision and control.**
metadata.videoTitle: This Makes Snowboarding Tricks Work – Ep 3

metadata.fullText: Hip shifted back, upper body forward, popping up and extending, keeping the weight set over the same point the whole way. Not popping the hips forward or anything. It's the same angle throughout the full duration. This is why some snowboards make things look so effortless. And that's because just by preemptively setting yourself up into the body posture or that's correct for the trick, you can simply go and execute straight power into it. And that's going to make it so these all work. If I was completely centered of my board and I tried to bounce this, it would be almost impossible to stagger the extension of my legs. But because my hips are shifted back here, it's almost impossible for me to go and pop in a way that wouldn't work for the jump. So, all I need to do is take the same riding position that I want to lock ride in, land in, and utilize it. For this clip, I'm demonstrating a really common mistake on a front side 360. Yet, you'll notice I'm landing it. So, why can I go and land a front side 360 even when trying to do everything wrong? And we can really see, look at how my hips are shifted towards this back leg, upper body pulled forward. The thing I really want to note about this is I'm not letting my weight shift towards my heel edge. I'm making sure to always go and pull my upper body forward in correlation to the hips going back. This front side 360 here is almost perfect except for the fact that he's going and having his weight shifted all the way to the heels. So, he's not pulling his upper body forward enough in correlation to uh the bend in his legs and that's making it so his rotation set over his heels. And the reason why I included that is because that is so important here, the balance. We're not trying to lean back. We're not trying to shift our weight all the way over.
metadata.text: **Maintain a consistent body posture with hips back and upper body forward throughout the trick, ensuring your weight stays centered over your board and not shifting to your heels.**
metadata.videoTitle: Why Riding Centred Is Holding You Back (and How to Fix It)

metadata.text: **Focus on progression and learning:** The transcript highlights the importance of effort, practice, and celebrating small wins, even when attempts aren't perfect, to build confidence and improve skills over time.
metadata.videoTitle: This Is What Progression Really Looks Like!

metadata.fullText: hello my brave soldiers in this video we're going to attempt to Impossible and try to wrap our minds around this 203e 40 of Madness this is truly a trick that boggles the mind and crushes the spirit so we're going to do our best to break it down figure out what the hell is happening in snowboarding to make this thing even possible it is truly mindboggling so do not attempt this at home I am somewhat professional so I the most qualified person to go and take on this feet and not only that we're also going to compare it to some of my riding to see how we Stack Up and how we can improve so let's go and break down the craziest trick I've ever seen done so the first thing we're going to note is this takeoff is absolutely perfect notice how he's coming into a jump all the way on the far side this is letting him take a very very light angle and that's really important for a big trick like this because it makes it so you can stand really tall over top of your board and the taller you are over the board the more range of motion and body movement you'll be able to use to generate power and he needs all the power he can get so he's getting on that heel Edge very early very slight and staying very tall and what he's trying to do while exiting this heelside turn is make sure that his board is maintaining pointed towards the left corner of the jump this is going to give him more range of motion to open the hips letting him wind up more and get more power and we can really see that his chest is already open hips open everything point pointed towards that corner and then this is really important as well he's doing a very similar spoon transition that you see from any snowboarder he's going from heelside to flat base as he's going up that transition it's a little bit delayed because it's such a big jump but he's still wanting to hold that little bit of flat Bess before getting on his Edge and as he gets onto his edge here it goes ooh that's really interesting look at how long his board is staying angled towards the left side I normally have my boards go and get straight pretty much as soon as I finish my wind up but he's holding that angle for a very long period of time what this is doing is making it so as he snaps off his board is staying a little bit straighter giving him more power okay let's look at the arm positioning here so he's staying very closed off something really cool to note here is look at how long he's delay in opening his arms he basically only op opens them and holds it for for a split millisecond before snapping this is because your core actually acts a bit like an elastic if you go and open up and hold a position for a long time and then try to move it won't have as much power as if you go and wind up and immediately snap so he's using that to his Advantage he's holding his chest open board open and then at the last second he's winding up so perfect timing he can mutely snap as hard as he can and he goes and finishes snapping right off a takeoff and this is where the trick starts getting pretty Nifty so when you snap this hard it's going to determine your axis of rotation a lot and he's doing something called the constant core let's just watch through this quick and you can see that he's maintaining the same axis rotation throughout the whole spin uh this is really important for these bigger rotations because it makes it so you can go and spot the knuckle the whole time so see his head is locked in place on that knuckle through the whole duration of his trick that is what's letting him go and spin this much and go and still get in control and see that's why we haven't been able to see these big of rotations before because people were doing them more Flippy and if you do something like a flip you're going to lose the spot every time so it gets very disorientating but here it honestly will look to him probably like he's not even spinning that much because his head will be so locked and focused and the key part to getting that axis rotation come in is all in this even though it's slightly corked look at how straight he's keeping his body this is because he's doing the perfect snapped over his tail where he's fully extended and in order to adjust his axis rotation he's not leaning forward he's not thring down he's just going and shifting his whole body to throw over that back leg giving him Max snap off his back foot think of this as like an ollie you pop off that back foot makes it so you snap off that tail get extra pop so shifting his whole weight back goes and gives him more pop more power while also putting him into the perfect axis rotation and that's really where this Mastery comes from is the ability to go and snap it and get holding that position so smooth so the Precision he needs to go and snap this hard will keeping this AIS of rotation is really just pretty hard to grasp everyone when they throw spins is like on a range and it's really hard to go and hit the perfect form this is the perfect angle perfect axis and let's watch his head positioning here so he snaps that hard yet he still grabs at 270 that is super proper a lot of people when by do these big tricks have a hard time get didn't grab but here grabs it right away and you can see that he's spotting forward the reason why he's spotting forward here is because he doesn't want to lead the rotation with his head even though he's doing a big spin leading the spin with your head will make it so your body needs to play catchup so it's actually the most efficient to generate momentum while keeping everything tight and connected that's making it so he's able to go and tighten up and immediately he's in his fully tucked position with everything tight working And sometimes on like a front three or a big jump, I'm only rotating my upper body this much leading the rotation. Again, one of the biggest problems in all of front side spins is over rotating the upper body off a lip, leaving the legs behind. So, we want to try and make it so our range of motion is here around here for the takeoff zone. So, we want to think about when that when we're trying to get this timing. The other thing that's really important for this is making sure that you're not winding up too soon. We don't want to be coming in tow edge, heel edge like this. It's just sort of awkward and unstable to hold your arms in that position for a long time. So, what you actually want to do is toe edge, heel edge, then close off because again, the biggest problem you're going to have is people preemptively opening your chest.

Intermediate is the stage that most riders get stuck on because you're getting down the mountain well enough and your body knows the movements, but the techniques that make all the movements work together aren't there yet. It can take years to get past this level or be much, much faster if your intentions are set towards the important fundamentals that more advanced riders use. And personally, I just slammed on my face until I figured it out. What I would not recommend advance 250 to 600 days. At advance, everything starts to click. You've discovered the stack position.

metadata.text: To maximize pop and control on jumps, focus on driving weight into your tail to snap off the lip, keeping your upper body centered and engaged with a slight rock motion.

metadata.text: **To achieve proper rotation for spins like a 540, maintain an upright and tall position off the takeoff, avoiding shoulder dips or a leaned-back posture that shifts your axis of rotation and leads to instability and potential crashes.**

metadata.text: Master backside setup carves by understanding their purpose: to prevent drift, build edge pressure, and position your upper body for powerful rotation by engaging your heel edge early and transitioning smoothly to your toe edge.
metadata.videoTitle: The Key To Spinning Backside

metadata.text: Prioritize getting comfortable with the feature itself before attempting complex maneuvers like spins.
metadata.videoTitle: I Made These Mistakes So You Don’t Have To! - EP 1

metadata.text: Avoid opening or closing your hips excessively to ensure a clean, controlled rotation during the spin.
metadata.videoTitle: Backside Wind-Ups Explained

metadata.fullText: And this is so beneficial because we want to go and pop up and not leave this point trying to maintain that same balance point through the in run, the takeoff in the air, and that'll make it so you can go and keep that balance on the landing. And this is so important to keep on the landing. Let's use this one as an example. So, first I'm coming into the takeoff. Nice and stacked over my board. You can see not too much bend, not too much hinge in the upper body.
metadata.text: Maintain a balanced, stacked stance over your board throughout the in-run and takeoff to ensure a stable landing.
metadata.videoTitle: Side-Hits Explained

metadata.fullText: Here's another thing both the sports have in common. Even if your technique is perfect, if your timing is even off by a fraction of a second, you're not going to get any power and you're not going to get anywhere with your technique. Learning to spin on a snowboard isn't just about learning how to twist harder. It's about going and connecting your motions, storing that energy, and executing them with the right timing in order to get that classic snap that can generate all the power you need to do any trick. And that's exactly the same principle we use when trying to throw a disc further.
metadata.text: **Focus on timing and connecting your movements to store and release energy efficiently, rather than just twisting harder, to generate power for spins.**
metadata.videoTitle: Why Playing DiscGolf Can Improve Your Snowboarding

metadata.fullText: And this is all best done with your weight slightly shift to the back foot. And then when you transition from your toe edge, heel edge, close off, snap, trying to feel like your maximum range of motion is at this 90 snap. By keeping the proper hinge in your upper body, not only will it make it so your rotation set over your toes, make it so you can't over snap, but it'll also make it so your spot is naturally there. So, from this point, all we need you to do is pop, keep our back front arm leading the rotation, and keep our head steady, and we'll be able to do a really fantastic front side 360. So, with all that in mind, here's a recap on a front side 360 that, if I'm being honest, isn't perfect. But, we're not looking for perfect. We're looking for a good enough spectrum that lets us land no matter what. So, we're coming in, adding that hinge in the upper body, preemptively adding bend into my legs when I'm still in the toe edge, waiting until I'm on my heel edge into closing off a little bit early, you might notice. And then I'm snapping, maintaining the same upper body hinge, making sure to not extend out of it, keeping my spot forward, leading with the front hand, and continuing the rotation. Here you'll see that I'm actually going a little bit big. And once you get really good at this, because the position's so stocked, so solid, you can just let your spot continue going downhill. And that's how you get those front-facing landings. So for everyone at home, remember, find that upper body hinge that lets you go and rotate without overextending and then work your movements through it. And once you can do that, just make sure that you're not going and hitting your wind up too soon and you're really delaying your setup carve. The more patient you can be, the less likely you are to go and stop your motion or over snap. Because when we have a limited motion, it's going to be really tricky.
metadata.text: Maintain an upper body hinge and slightly shift weight to your back foot for a controlled, powerful rotation, leading with your front arm and keeping your head steady.
metadata.videoTitle: How To “ACTUALLY” Frontside 360

metadata.fullText: This is going to make it so I have to go and reconnect my upper and lower body. Because when you actually snap this much, you can't go and just continue and hold this motion. Instead, you need to go and let the legs play catchup. And when the legs play catch-up, it's the same thing as using counter rotation. So here you can see I'm basically just taking off in the straight position. No extra rotation being generated, over snapping, and needing to counter rotate it a whole 270 to get it around. And you're just not going to get that smooth, effortless throw when doing it.
metadata.text: Let your legs "catch up" to your upper body's movement to avoid over-rotating and ensure a smooth, controlled spin.
metadata.videoTitle: How To “ACTUALLY” Frontside 360

metadata.fullText: Kicking my board up like this sort of left me stuck in the sideways position. So reaching for the grab too soon on this trick can leave you in a position where you don't have the right arc in order to get back to your feet. And then another thing that happened here is I went smaller than I expected. So I didn't have enough time to redirect. And this actually resulted in a really painful slam where my arm came down and I pressed it through. And this is one of the worst falls you can do on like backside 180s is having your hand come down and get jammed in. The alternative was slamming my face. So we had to sacrifice the arm. But it's like a week later and my arm's still really suffering from this. So when you're going and doing this trick and especially if you're trying it off of something high consequence like a jump, make sure that you're being patient, you're getting that good pop, and you're not rushing the grab and you're making sure to not knuckle the jump because it's really important to go and actually get into a sweet spot to go and match up the angle of the takeoff.
metadata.text: Be patient with your grab on backside 180s, ensuring good pop and matching the takeoff angle to avoid getting stuck sideways and risking injury from an unexpected landing.

metadata.text: **Master counter-rotation:** Utilize early upper body rotation to control spins, allowing for more precise grabs and preventing over-rotation, especially on larger jumps.
metadata.videoTitle: How Kevin Backstrom Makes Every Trick Look Effortless!

metadata.fullText: All of these little challenges can be surprisingly annoying for beginners. Skiing doesn't have nearly as many of these small quirks. If you do want to learn to snowboard, watch tutorials, wear protection, and focus on fundamentals before chasing speed or steeper runs. For both sports, when you fall, go with the momentum. Don't try to catch yourself with your hands. Wrist injuries are super common in beginners.
metadata.text: When falling, go with the momentum and avoid catching yourself with your hands to prevent wrist injuries.
metadata.videoTitle: Skiing vs Snowboarding – What’s REALLY Better?

metadata.text: Maintain an upright upper body and bend your back leg while focusing weight on the balls of your feet to stay within your effective range of motion for straight airs.

metadata.text: Keep your upper body stacked directly over your snowboard to maintain balance and control.

metadata.fullText: That's all you need to do. We don't need to do a massive pop, a big jump to get onto the rail. We don't want to fully extend. Instead, it's just like a little micro jump off your calves. That's going to keep that motion. And then we do this as we slightly shift our weight to our back foot. Shifting up and just putting that pressure micro pop. So, it looks like this. You're coming into a rail stacked over the rail. Micro pop coming in. And because you have this hinge in your body, it's really easy to move your legs out independently. If you're really tall, it comes hard to move your legs, make any adjustments. But this sort of works like a claw machine where my upper body and lower body can now move independently from one another because I have this nice athletic stance. You can also think of it as a squat. You don't want to be squatting like this all the way down. It's going to be too stiff.
metadata.text: Initiate rail transfers with a small, calf-driven "micro pop" and a slight shift of weight to your back foot for an athletic stance that allows independent leg movement.
metadata.videoTitle: The Technique Pros Use for Effortless Rails

metadata.text: Get taller, open hips and chest toward the jump corner before spinning for a powerful and consistent rotation.

metadata.fullText: But on a back seven, we need enough power to get the full two 360s around. Whenever you're generating power and range of motion, you need to absolutely need to make sure that your upper body is never coming up and throwing flat or dipping down. The way that we do this is by keeping our spine straight. A lot of people when we're keeping our spine straight though, think about pushing their hips out. And while yes, we want to make sure that we're not like too far like this because that's going to make our arms go down. We need that slight bit of bend in our legs so we can keep our weight over the balls of our feet.
metadata.text: To generate power for a back seven, maintain a straight spine and a slight bend in your legs, keeping your weight over the balls of your feet, while ensuring your upper body doesn't dip or throw flat.

metadata.text: **Don't rush tricks on features you're not ready for, and ensure you have proper equipment and jump size before attempting advanced maneuvers.**
metadata.videoTitle: I Made These Mistakes So You Don’t Have To! - EP 4

metadata.text: Maintain an upright, neutral body position with your chest up to avoid falling off balance during the spin.
metadata.videoTitle: The Secret To Spinning Like A Pro! – Core Moves Every Snowboarder Needs - EP 4

metadata.text: Avoid over-rotating or looking too far over your shoulder during the backside 360 to ensure control.
metadata.videoTitle: The Secret To Spinning Like A Pro! – Core Moves Every Snowboarder Needs - EP 4

metadata.text: Maintain a centered, balanced approach to jumps, avoiding excessive toe-edge pressure to prevent unintentional spinning.
metadata.videoTitle: I Never Expected to Learn This Trick:) - Japan Vlog - 4

metadata.text: Improve frontside 360s by focusing on a powerful approach and a clean toe edge transition.
metadata.videoTitle: Start Grabbing Your Frontside 360s with these Small Changes

metadata.text: Counter-rotate your upper body late by using your back arm to pull the rotation, improving jump control.
metadata.videoTitle: Teaching My Sister How to Backside 360 the Right Way (Live Coaching)

metadata.fullText: So see here, he's coming in, spotting, and now he's going and pulling his head around. And look at how much he's tucking into his shoulder. I know I normally say you don't want to tuck your head into your shoulder, but the way that Liam does his tricks is more flippy based. So that means he needs to go and tuck his shoulder in order to change that axis rotation. And that's what's letting him get these really unique axises of rotation is taking the head.
metadata.text: For flippy tricks, tuck your head into your shoulder to change axis of rotation and achieve unique spins.
metadata.videoTitle: How Liam Brearley Uses Counter-Rotation To "DOMINATE"

metadata.text: Maintain a balanced 'stack position' with bent legs and upper body, centered over the balls of your feet, for optimal control and power.
metadata.videoTitle: The Foundation of All Snowboarding — Train This Off-Season!

metadata.text: Initiate spins by pressing down on the tail throughout the lip of the jump, maintaining tail pressure for a stable rotation, rather than popping an ollie.
metadata.videoTitle: You’re Not Supposed to Jump or Ollie When Doing Tricks

metadata.text: Open your hips to facilitate proper body positioning and edge control during the carve.

metadata.text: Maintain a tall, centered stance with minimal setup carving to improve toe-edge transitions and rotation wind-up.
