Getting that extension pop off the tail, then counter rotation, but he's adding maximum bend to his body, shifting all the way over to his back leg. And then as he pops, even though he's getting maximum extension, look at how much he's pulling his upper body forward. The more you extend your legs, the more you need to keep your upper body going forward in order to keep that center of balance over the balls of your feet. Because if he bounced up in this angle here, he's going to be slipping out heel heavy. And this makes it so as he brings his legs up, he's able to immediately enter his boardside position seamlessly. And then he has enough sideways momentum so the nose just needs to get over and then it can rock him. And you can see him go and push that foot down. Boom. And this is something you can do when you have this really good position bend in the legs is you can actually move your legs independently. And that's exactly what he's doing here to get this little pop out of clean position. Landing in basically the same position he took offy smexy man. What? Where is he coming from for this hand drag? Miller flip. Uh this is a trick I actually got but I do it with two hands. The one hand is sort of cooler. Uh what's he doing here?
metadata.text: To achieve a seamless board slide, maximize leg extension and pop off the tail, while simultaneously pulling your upper body forward to maintain balance over your feet.
metadata.videoTitle: This Is Why Rene Rinnekangas Is My Favourite Snowboarder!

metadata.fullText: So, the next premotion I do is flattening the base of my snowboard. The reason why we're flattening out the base of our snowboards when we're going and positioning from heel edge to toe edge is because it just increases the size of the turn radius. If you go straight from heels to toes, it's going to go and have a bit of a pendulum effect where your momentum is going to wash you back and forth really aggressively. And that's going to make it so it's way harder to go and control that edge because as your board's momentuming, it's going to have more sideways momentum. Sideways momentum is going to be harder to go and gripping your edge. So, by having a good upper body and then flattening out our base, we're slowing down our sideways momentum and that's going to make it easier to grip in. every turn in every carb in snowboarding, you can think about it like drifting a corner on a car. When you go and hit a corner on a car and you go and hit it with good tires, good traction, you can go and turn at a really high speed without your back tires skidding out and causing you to drift. But if the roads are wet, your tires are run out and then you go and hit the corner with the same amount of speed, you're going to go and start to skid. So that's exactly how snowboarding works. It's a formula of grip versus speed. So the more sideways momentum you have, the more grip you need to have in order to counter it. So this snow here is super perfect, super groomed. So that means I'm going to have a lot of grip, a lot of friction, a lot of traction. Uh, and that traction is going to let me go and dig in my edge more aggressively than normal. These carves like this wouldn't be possible. And if they are, it'd be a lot harder on more icy conditions that you would generally find. This is about as snow as good as the snow gets. So with that in mind, we can go and be a little bit more aggressive with these movements. And we're still going though and trying to maintain these same principles through the whole motion. So heel edge lightening up to the flat edge base.
metadata.text: **Flatten your board's base between edge transitions to control sideways momentum, increase turn radius, and improve edge grip.**
metadata.videoTitle: Carving Deep Dive

metadata.text: Maintain an athletic, forward-hinged stance with bent knees, keeping your upper body stacked over the board to improve grip and turn depth.
metadata.videoTitle: Carving Deep Dive

metadata.fullText: Because if you go and try to lift and extend upwards with your torso, that's going to put you in a taller position and that's going to shift you closer and closer towards your heel edge. So here, I'm maintaining a very dramatic over the toe position. So as I go and pop up and extend my legs, my upper body is still stationary. And from this stationary position, I can utilize counter rotation. And just pay attention to how subtle my upper body is here. It's coming up, counter rotating, hardly moving at all. Set over that front foot, catching the rail, and then just balancing through. And you can see I'm sliding off a little bit. But because I had enough bend in my legs, enough tilt in my upper body, I can go and shift where my center of balance is, allowing me to maintain contact into the end of a feature. Even when doing something like a front lip gap, we're still keeping the same principles, even though we're trying to generate so much height. So here I'm maintaining tail contact with the lip of the jump as long as possible.
metadata.text: When popping for a rail or gap, keep your upper body stationary and over your front foot, allowing you to counter-rotate and control your balance.

metadata.fullText: Push forward. Go. Snap to that tail. And the next part that you really want to train besides that little bit of weight shift and angle here is now continue momentum. This is going to be a big breakthrough because if you go and snap and cut it short, you're going to be here and you'll need to look over your shoulder to try elongate it and pull that spin around. It's going to go and throw everything out of whack. So, what you want to do is snap here, keep your head centered, and then pull your back arm leading all the way into 270. At this point, everything should be connecting. That's when you hit the grab, and that's when you pull through again.
metadata.text: After snapping your tail, keep your head centered and pull your back arm through to fully extend your spin, connecting your movements and leading to a successful grab.

metadata.fullText: And this is actually going to be the key position we use for all the rotations. Because when we're like this, we can track our head on the middle of a jump and we can go and rotate the whole way through where if we have our body straight like this and we try to go and put our head down, we're going to be stiff and that's going to make it more likely so our rotation is set on a backwards axis instead of that nice balls of feet rotation plane that we're really looking for in trampolining. So once your arms are nice and stacked, we want to go and just try to use a little bit of counter rotation. And once you feel comfortable opening 90, counter rotating, let's go and space this out.
metadata.text: **Adopt a stacked, counter-rotated body position with your head centered over the jump to achieve a fluid, "balls of feet" rotation.**

metadata.fullText: That's where the second head motion comes into play. As we rotate that backside 720, get to 270. We need to make sure that we're pulling and leading with our neck, our shoulders, and our torso all combined in order to get that spin around. And it looks like this. So, we're coming up strong position, keeping that center of balance, using that free bounce system. If we need one, two, three.
metadata.text: To complete a backside 720, actively lead the rotation with your neck, shoulders, and torso from the 270-degree mark.

metadata.fullText: I want you to when you're spinning front side 360ies on the spin it as if you're trying to spin hard weight off your toes. This will make it so as you pop and explode, your weight is going to be set over the balls of your feet. This will help fix the other problem of making sure that your spot doesn't go over the shoulder. As soon as we spot over our shoulder, it elongates our core, sets our weight over our heels, and it's going to put us on that offaxis throw. So, we need to make sure that our upper body's pulled over, our weights hyperaggressively set over the balls of our feet. So, I want you to try hold this super over the balls of feet position and try not to extend out of it too much. We're going warm up with just doing a 180 180. And when we're doing this, we're trying to keep our spot set on the center of the trampoline the whole time while keeping our chin centered. So, see here, I'm not looking and pulling my neck this way or this way. Head locked straight down. And as I throw, I'm keeping my head in that stationary position. As we're going and doing these rotations, we're trying to keep our head as stationary as possible. You don't want to be ripping your head as you throw your spin because it's going to elongate you, disconnect you, and make it so you can't see where you're at. So, let's go and do that drill with that in mind. Bend the legs, hinge forward, eyes down, rotate 180, 180. And when we want to start adding more power and more jump, we're going to start extending, but we need to make sure that our final point of extension still has our weight set over here. So, we're rotating like this. See how my upper body is angled forward? Weight set over the balls of feet even as my legs fully extend. And this is going to let us maintain that rotation point, our spot at the center of the trampoline. So, it looks like this. Rotating, spotting through. And we can build this up to bigger spins as well. So for 540s, rotating, coming through.
metadata.text: To improve frontside 360s, focus on aggressively shifting your weight to the balls of your feet during the pop, keeping your head stationary and spotting the center to maintain balance and control.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Train Frontside Spins On Tramp

metadata.text: Focus on maintaining balance and control while spotting the center of the trampoline.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Train Frontside Spins On Tramp

metadata.fullText: I'm very excited because in this video we're going to cover the most important trick in all of snowboarding, all of trampolining, and that is the backside 360. This trick is so important because we're learning so many fundamentals and it's the building block of so many tricks to come. First things first, you want to make sure that you have the previous steps dialed and that's having the head position here and the ability to use counter rotation. And the biggest problem people have with the backside 360 is two front. First, they'll go and try way over snap it and then they'll have to control it. Pair that with the next mistake that is looking over the shoulder and you have a really hard to control rotation that you won't be able to build off for bigger spins in the future. So, let's focus on how to fix that. The first thing we need to fix is making sure that we're not trying to use too much extension and we're not trying to use too much throw. For backside 360 on a trampoline, we don't need to throw at all. Watch this. I can just pop up, counter rotate, pull it through. It's that simple. If you keep your head position, right core, I don't think I even need to use my arms.
metadata.text: Master the backside 360 by focusing on counter-rotation and a consistent head position, avoiding over-snapping or looking too far over your shoulder, as the trick relies on controlled pop, not excessive throwing.

metadata.text: **Focus on foundational techniques and gradual progression:** Instead of immediately attempting advanced tricks, build your frontside and cab takeoffs by staying more stacked over your board and relying less on edge pressure, mirroring successful backside spin techniques, to prepare for bigger airbags.

metadata.fullText: The way we get this tail pressure isn't through doing an oie because we don't want extra height onto the rail. When we go and get height onto the rail, we have to go and catch it and we need enough room in our legs to absorb it. So, if you jump up really high and slam really hard, it's just going to increase the impact for no reason. So, we're trying to get on these rails as subtly as possible. What isn't possible with a full scaled ollie. So, instead, what we want to do is have our hips slightly shifted towards our back foot and pull our upper body forward in correlation.
metadata.text: Shift your hips towards your back foot and pull your upper body forward to subtly get onto rails, avoiding a full ollie that creates unnecessary height and impact.
metadata.videoTitle: Watch This Before Your First 50-50s!

metadata.text: Maintain a stacked body position with bent knees and your chest forward over your toes to keep your weight centered and prevent falling backward.
metadata.videoTitle: Stop Slipping Out On Boardslides!!!

metadata.text: Pre-angle your body towards the side hit and extend your legs while reducing toe edge pressure just before takeoff to launch from a flat base.
metadata.videoTitle: Side-Hits Explained

metadata.text: Use bent knees, a slightly hinged upper body, and controlled bounces to initiate and control rotations for snowboard tricks.
metadata.videoTitle: Trampoline Basics for Snowboarders | Learn to Tramp Like a Pro – Ep. 1

metadata.text: Maintain a strong, flexible stance with a wide range of motion to handle position variations without losing control.

metadata.fullText: First, even though we want to make sure that we're not going and holding our closed off position too long, we really need to make sure that we're not riding in with our chest open, we still need that extra range of motion in order to get the pop. So, what I recommend doing is delaying your setup carve into around the spoon of a jump and then only once you're on your heels, then close off with your body. And when you're doing this, pull over your body like you're doing a hardway front one. The only reason we're not doing a hard way front one here is because we're using this as a building block trick and also hard way will make it so you can't pre-pin and it's going to induce two-footed jumping more. But if you prefer doing a hardway front one, that's an easy cheat because once it's hard way and you have your weight set over your toes, it'll make it so your axis of rotation and your pivot point is your toe edge. So much easier to get around and so much more control.
metadata.text: Delay your setup carve into the spoon of the jump, then close your body like a hardway front one to initiate a controlled, poppy rotation off your heelside edge.

metadata.text: Maintain an upper body position forward to improve your ability to rotate.

metadata.fullText: But because Ben's turn radius was off, in order to keep his board straight, he was preemptively jumping his board. So he didn't go and hook and start breaking at the waist. So this is showing big signs of imbalance, making it so he needs to rush the position. That said, he gets a good popup, and there's a lot to really like here about his fundamental air control. First, look at his head position. It's really patient, and his shoulders are relatively squared. The reason why this is such a good sign is a lot of people at this stage are scared to get the 360 around. So, their head will be pulling towards the shoulder and looking over the shoulder or tucking in this way. It's going to throw off your balance because it's going to set your rotation too much over your back foot. So, Ben is doing something here that is really a big reason why he was able to make so much progression and so much control on his back freeze. And that is popping up patient with that upper body, continuing that upper body rotating through. And look at this back arm pulling the whole way. Pulling the back arm like this really helps because it makes it so your chest is rotating, your arm's pulling, and that's going to let your head spot the landing sooner. And the most important thing is with your upper body rotated, you can then pull it back across from you in order to counter rotate to land. And that gives you a lot of control. If you're going and undershooting or overshooting, you can control the speed of your rotation. One of the things that was really throwing Ben off is as he was coming on the fake snow, if he messed up his setup carve, it would sort of mess up his whole takeoff and throw. So that's just showing us that he has a very streamlined system, and if he wasn't falling back completely, it would go and throw him off a little bit. So today, the fixes we were trying to make were increasing the angle of his board, delaying his setup card, so his getting onto his toe edge later, and this should make it so he can increase the range of motion in his upper body. The one thing I want to point out here is even though his upper body is super wound up to the point that I'd say this is maximum wind up he'd want to do. Look at how square his hips are and look at how straight his board is. This is making it so he's not using the biggest rotation. What led us into another problem we faced and that is that he was trying to set the rotation too much with his arms and not enough with his legs. And in order to keep a straight edge, he wasn't able to throw it as early as he needed to. You can see as he's taking off here, his upper body is rotated slightly closed off. This would be really good for like a backside 540, but for a backside 720, we need that upper body to be rotated towards the tail of the snowboard completely 90 almost. And we want the hips to be following. But because he's having this disconnect of his hips not falling and his legs not falling, he's getting this dip position where he's popping up and pushing. And this is where we can really see that problem with that two-foot jump. two-foot jump, legs super straight, disconnecting the core from the lower body. And this is causing a lot of funk. And this is one of the reasons why he's getting so unbalanced and not consistent. Here we can really see that he's trying to go and open up his hips more and get more angle by adding his arm over here, arm over here. We'll talk about this more later, but that's increasing his angle towards the corner. But because he's so he's not dramatic enough with it and not smooth enough with it, he's not giving himself a really strong spin platform. And that's really the biggest thing that you can do to increase consistency on your spins is build that platform. And that's why even though he's working on 720s here, the same things could be worked on on 360s, 5407s, you can just work on more fundamental principles at the same time when you're doing 720s. So that was the focus. But if this was a onso situation, I'd probably have him doing a bunch more backside 360s in order to go and fix this. So let's go and get a good one here. Doop. So you can just see sort of inconsistent. Not really not really it yet. Here we're having some 360s. And I was trying to go and explain to him that we don't want that like tail uh coming up early popping too much, but this was just making it so he was too stiff. And you can see for yourself not really having the same control that we were having on day one. And that's a really normal part of progression. You take a step forward, you take a couple steps back, but fixing these fundamental core principles pay off in the long run. So, it's important to not be scared of making changes because that's one of the main reasons we were able to get Ben to go and accelerate his learning this fast and get his skill level this high in such a short amount of time is he was willing to make any change if it would help his riding. And because of that, we were able to really streamline the process. So here he's getting a little bit more bend in the legs, a little bit more angle. Let's look at his board. Slightly more angle towards the corner of a jump.
metadata.text: To improve spin consistency and control, focus on rotating your hips and legs more effectively, rather than relying solely on your upper body and arms, to create a stable spin platform.

metadata.fullText: Anyway, a bit more bend of the legs would have really helped him there. Watch this. Oh yeah, this is pretty classic for a mistake you'll see when people are hitting pow cliff features. What's happening is honestly the same thing as that last clip. He's coming out of his pow slash and trying to redirect his turn, but because he's going and leaning so much on his heel edge. Look at how his weight's completely set over those heels as he comes off a lip. He doesn't try to reenter. So he's riding off a jump. We can see his base coming and his weights just set way too much over those heels. He would have in order to have his legs this straight in this position, he would have had to have his upper body way over here to counterbalance it. But he didn't try to counterbalance with the upper body at all. Just holding that strong position. And because of that, as he came into the snow, he smashed that same angle the whole way. And if you want to land a steep powder thing like this, you need to make sure that you're over top of your board. you're not rotating preemptively.
metadata.text:
Here's a concise, actionable bullet point:

*   Maintain a balanced stance, keeping your weight centered over your board with bent knees, rather than leaning excessively on your heel edge when launching off pow features to ensure a stable landing.
metadata.videoTitle: Why These Snowboarding Crashes Happened!

metadata.fullText: Oh my god. Okay. Okay. That was criminal. That was criminal. So, this is something we see really common when people are learning to snowboard, and that is leg locking himself. So, see how he has like a little bit of bend here, but this leg's locked out, and he's going and just rounding to try to keep that center of balance. Uh, this is just making it so he doesn't have any micro control in his legs. And now he's trying to change his momentum too soon, and that's just causing that full clip. And honestly, the worst case scenario. So, how do you avoid this? If he just went and had a bit more bend in this back leg and a little like evened up with this, this fall wouldn't have happened. It's the combination of trying to go into that toe edge turn too soon and having a compromised leg position that made it so he's susceptible to this edge catch. For anyone watching at home, it's almost impossible to edge catch if you actively are riding in a stack position. So, keeping your weight set slightly over the balls of your feet, legs back, hips back. Uh, here I'll draw the little position quick. Do upper body here, legs back here with a little bit of bend like this. Uh, that's a bad drawing. But from that position, you're rocking back and forth. And as long as you don't try to turn too soon for your turn radius and your sideways momentum, it's going to be impossible to catch. But when you go and straighten yourself up this much, you really need to make sure your timing and control is locked in, or else you're going to be really susceptible to catching your edge. So, anyone out there struggling with edge catching, uh, I made a good video on it, and I'll be making some more of this summer, but it's all about your stacked form and making sure that you're not relying on straight-legged leaning too much when riding. Here, this is heel side 50/50 clap, flip over. This happens to the best of us. Uh, heelside 50/50s are a bit of a buzzkill. Um, but basically what's happening here is he's popping too far out of his position. So now his weight is completely set over his heels and that's just making it so he doesn't have any control. If he wanted to do this at this low of a speed, I would have wanted to see a lot more bend in the legs, a lot more bend in the upper body so he could go and pop and get that motion without overextending himself.
metadata.text: Maintain a "stacked" riding position with bent knees and hips back, avoiding straight-legged leaning, to prevent edge catches and improve control.
metadata.videoTitle: Why These Snowboarding Crashes Happened!

metadata.text: Improve landing straighter by maintaining a bent-leg, 'rock' motion and leaning your upper body forward with weight on the balls of your feet.
metadata.videoTitle: Improving Your Straight Airs

metadata.fullText: So there's no point in trying to keep pressure onto that edge because I'm lightweight. I'm using this moment of unweightness. I can go and change my upper body and lower body positioning with minimal impact to my actual edge line. And then what I'm doing here is I'm going and taking my right hand and just pulling it slightly open. Slightly opening the chest, slightly rotating the head. And that's letting me slightly open my hips. So then when I go and make contact with that heel edge, I can instantly go and start locking down. And that's why we're getting this turn radius so quick. And then when going entering the toe edge, what are we doing? The exact opposite. This hand's coming back behind me. My front hand's coming in front, but we're still doing the same process. Going hitting flat base, getting on that toe edge, and then loading the pressure in. So, see how my hand comes down a little bit later after my edge. So, I'm going setting that edge and once that edge is in, that's when I drive the power into it. And you can see it because the turn radius starts increasing. This is how you can go get low to the snow. Because if you just try to get low to the snow when you're still flat base edge isn't in, it's going to be really tough to go and get enough traction that you don't fall over. And then, how do we go and exit this position? We come up and do the exact same thing. Opening the chest slightly downhill. You can see the hand that's letting me go and hit my heel edge position. And then I'm just loading into it. And then the legs catching up with the other body is what causes this turn.
metadata.text: **Use moments of unweightness to subtly initiate body rotations (hand, chest, head) to pre-set your hips, allowing for immediate edge engagement and quicker turn initiation.**
metadata.videoTitle: Carving Deep Dive

metadata.text: Improve frontside spin technique by initiating rotation with your hips, torso, and chest before your arms for a smoother, more powerful movement.
metadata.videoTitle: 5 Snowboard Exercises I Do Every Day — Here's Why

metadata.text: **Avoid "breaking at the waist" by reaching for a grab before your board leaves the jump; instead, focus on proper body extension and hip shift for a powerful, controlled takeoff.**

metadata.text: To smoothly transition off of a front lipslide, immediately add counter-rotation to exit the feature.

metadata.text: Use a low arm pre-position followed by shoulder-driven lift to generate smooth power.

metadata.text: Engage your core and initiate a slight rocking motion for better control and balance throughout the jump.

metadata.text: Keep your upper body stable and hinged, with a balanced stance over the balls of your feet during approach and on the rail.

So as he keeps his eyes on his the knuckle here he can sense that he still has a lot of air time he still has a lot of room to move. metadata.text: To land a frontside 360 looking forward, maintain a tall upper body, spot the knuckle early, and add extra rotation to allow your legs to catch up and control the spin.

metadata.text: Allow your legs to follow the upper body's lead, catching up to maintain balance throughout the spin.

metadata.fullText: Say you're doing like a backside 540, you can pop it up, counter rotate, and when you're coming into the landing with less rotational energy. So, not only is it great for going and building a whole rotation, it's also slowing down your maximum rotation velocity. That's going to make it way easier to land these tricks. But let's focus on how we can use it to go and build our fundamentals.
metadata.text: To make landings easier, counter-rotate during the trick to reduce rotational energy before impact.
metadata.videoTitle: Unlock Total Control with Counter Rotation – Tramp Like a Snowboarder Ep 2

metadata.text: Avoid over-rotating off the takeoff, and instead focus on controlled rotation to consistently land a backside five.
metadata.videoTitle: 80% Of Riders Make This Mistake On Backside Spins - Video Analysis

metadata.text: Throw your arms in line with the upper body angle to avoid waist bends and maintain a stable spinning axis.
metadata.videoTitle: 80% Of Riders Make This Mistake On Backside Spins - Video Analysis

metadata.fullText: And then we need to remember we don't actually need a fast aggressive motion on a front side 360. We're not trying to go and jump and extend and throw the spin. Instead, we're just trying to channel this energy through. So, coming in, channeling, channeling, channeling all the way through. And I want you to notice something quick here. See how my legs are extending? What I'm doing with these legs isn't going and trying to jump off. Jumping off of a feature actually gives you no extra height on any trick. If your legs start lifting upwards, you're losing potential energy and it's going to limit your sideways momentum. So, why are my legs going from bent to tall? This is because I'm trying to go and maintain pressure with a jump.
metadata.text: Focus on channeling energy through a smooth extension of your legs from bent to tall, rather than aggressively jumping, to maintain momentum and avoid losing potential height.
metadata.videoTitle: Unlock Your Frontside Potential This Summer!—No Equipment Required

Not too much, but just enough that your back hand is towards your back glute. So, when I have my hand here, I can go and utilize counter rotation of the hips. The next thing we're going to want to do for this is just grind it out. Get really comfortable with pulling it through. This should be second nature to you before going and trying the actual 360 because this is much easier. Now, let's talk about snapping position with the shoulders. A lot of people think that when you want to spin, you got to drive your shoulders and close them off completely. But actually, we hardly need any rotational force with the upper body. Once we start moving on to like 720s, we'll want to leave rotation more with our upper body to generate more rotation. But on a backside 360, if we go and throw our upper body too much, it's going to disconnect our core and make it really hard to connect it and control the power. So, as we're going and throwing the spin, coming out for the neutral, I want you to have your shoulder not coming further than the inside of your knee. So, see how the shoulder's coming inside of the knee. And the next thing we're going to talk about is rounding.
metadata.text: Lead the backside 360 rotation with your upper body just enough to bring your back hand towards your back glute, keeping your lead shoulder no further than the inside of your knee.

metadata.text: Initiate your frontside spin by pre-positioning your upper body low and angled towards your heel edge as you approach on your toe edge, eliminating unnecessary up-and-down movement.

metadata.fullText: Because I have this stagger in my upper and lower body, I can move my legs independently. So here, I'm pushing my back leg down, letting my front leg coming up, and you're going to see that I'm coming in tailheavy. Tail heavy is basically the safety net of jumping because it lets us go and disperse our impact a little bit more and catch ourselves. We'll go and have some more examples for this, but you can see a very tall extended body slightly set over the tail and legs almost completely extended but not fully. This position is actually perfect. And while I'm doing it, I'm maintaining a slight hinge. And now, as I absorb the impact, I let myself disperse into a more exaggerated version of that position. hips back, upper body forward. Weight still set over the balls of the feet because we're pushing the hips back. It's going to want to shift you to the heels. So, we need to really pull that upper body forward in order to stay balanced. And the reason why we can get away with landing like this is even though my hips are positioned so my weight's over my back foot because my upper body is pulled forward, when we combine that with impact, it's naturally going pull my body into the landing direction of the slope. This is the technique used by every pro snowboarder, including someone as legendary as Arthur Longo. Pops up, keeps that angle, lands tail heavy, pushes through. So, as he leaves the takeoff, upper body slightly forward, hips slightly back. And as he goes and jumps and bends his legs up, his upper body keeps pulling forward and his hips keep shifting back. And as he comes into the landing, he now fully extends into this position. And look at how aggressive his tail angle is, giving him so much room to absorb it. But he's not going and leaning his whole body towards that tail. Instead, that upper body is rotated open, shifting towards that front foot, hinge of the upper body, keeping the weight over the balls of his feet. So, as he comes and tries to disperse the energy, tail first to the front leg. And as he absorbs it, he gets pushed back more into that position, but he doesn't slip out because his upper body keeps pulling forward in correlation to the hips being set back, allowing him to go and absorb a lot of impact. Red Gerard uses this every time he's finishing a back 18 back triple.
metadata.text: **Land tail-heavy by extending your legs and shifting your hips back while keeping your upper body forward and rotated open to absorb impact and maintain balance.**

metadata.text: Avoid closing off your upper body on the heel edge, as this results in being too far back on your heels at the lip and hinders your pop.

metadata.fullText: And that way, we're having a stagger in the bend in our legs. We're having more contact with the jump because we're leaving off our tail. And that way we don't need to even worry about extending because if you extend out of your position that you want to be in the air, you'll need to re-enter that position that's going to add a big time delay.
metadata.text: **Leave the jump off your tail to create a staggered leg bend and maintain air position, avoiding a time-delaying extension.**

let my chest come down as my hips go out here you can see I'm not doing it completely perfect because I'm getting more and more pressure onto my tow Edge ideally your Center balance is staying at exactly the same point I'll leave you with this one final note every motion you do in snowboarding is going to try break your stack position be it carving be it rails be it spins if you open your hips it's going to go and change the variables you need for a stack position but through working through your stack position figuring out how to go and wind up load up and explode off your tail all when maintaining that same Center of balance that's what gives you control and that's what gives you power so if you're struggling with your straight airs you're struggling with your turns you're struggling with any part in your snowboarding think about your positioning think about how your body is moving and ask yourself am I maintaining a stack position through this whole range of motion if you're doing a front side board slide and slipping out ask yourself are you completely in the same balance point through the whole trick if you're doing a spin and lose balance ask yourself am I going and doing anything that's thrilling off my balance at any point you do that and train it and it will make you a fantastic snowboarder that can shred any terrain and do any trick

If I'm going and winding up a backside spin and I'm going just straight position, heels to toes. I'm here. That's only giving my hips this much room to rotate. metadata.fullText: Have you ever wondered what level of snowboarder you really are? In this video, I'm going to break down each level of snowboarding, the challenges you'll face, the techniques that will help you progress, and what it takes to move on to the next stage. Knowing where you're at can make your training smarter, your sessions more fun, and progression faster. Beginner, 5 to 30 days. If you're still falling and switching from heel edge to toe edge feels near impossible, welcome to beginner. You're finally getting comfortable side slipping and testing your toe edge. You've got a heel edge position and a toe edge position, but nothing in between. Riding greens is exciting, but scary. Blues are manageable if you go slow, and blacks survival mode. The main goal here is staying upright, learning to trust your balance, edge engagement, and stance. At this stage, small winds feel huge, linking turns, staying on your feet, and actually enjoying a run without panic.

metadata.text: To eliminate drift and create a strong snap for frontside spins, enter the jump with a light toe edge, transition to a flat base through the spoon of the jump, and then engage your heel edge for the wind-up and rotation.

metadata.text: Enter the jump with a light toe edge to initiate the spin and eliminate unwanted drifting.
metadata.videoTitle: The Key To Spinning Frontside

metadata.fullText: You just won't have the range of motion to utilize it. This is the contrast to that position. See how my upper body is completely centered in my snowboard? My hips are squared and just everything's connected and tight. This position, while strong and sturdy, doesn't have any flexibility or move moability. So, I would never be able to go and squat down nearly that low. So, when I want to squat lower, use more range of motion, I shift the hips back exactly like you're seeing here. See how the knees are pulling back, the upper body is pulling forward. So, my center of balance is still over that same centered point, but I'm getting there with the contrast of the hips back, chest forward. This is what opens up the possibility of fast edge changes and fluidity throughout your motion. Because when you're going and keeping yourself completely centered and squared, you are now only moving on an up and down spectrum. Shifting the hips back doesn't only increase your up and down range of motion, but it also increases how much you can open your upper body. This makes it so you can drop lower, see where you're going more, and utilize not only up and down, but also rotational energies in order to elongate and put more power through any single turn you do on your snowboard. If we look at this posture here, we can see he's very tall and set over his front foot. This makes it so he's lifting up his back foot. And when this is useful in some instances, it's only useful with actual range of motion. So, the reason why this rider feels so stiff and uncomfortable is because his hips are shifted forward instead of backwards and he has a tall body. That's a really big part about this is you need to make sure that you have your upper body hinged forward in order to go and pull those hips back because if you're straight like a starecrow, you're not going to be able to go and start moving these body parts independently to one another and that means you won't be able to channel motion. This technique right here almost looks textbook. Her upper body's hinged forwards. There's a little bit of bend in her back leg and more extension in the front leg. The problem is she's rotating her chest too drastic for how much bend she has in her legs. This is because she's trying to go and get preempia heel side turn. But she would have naturally flown into that turn if she simply kicked those hips back more, letting her go and keep this upper body hinge, but with the correlation of the legs being pulled back. So slightly shifting the hips back is the difference between this girl doing a more advanced turn compared to her very beginner level snowboarding. This is a more intermediate level rider and we can really see it in action. Notice how his upper body and legs are completely centered over his snowboard. He doesn't have any back and forth mechanics going.

When falling on you want to really make sure that you're not going and jamming your arms into the for very soft surfaces so you're able to just go and sling up flat on your side. So I want you before trying any tricks is just get comfortable with going and coming up and rolling to your back. The more you can get to your back, the safer it'll be. First, we're not trying to fully juice every single bounce up in the air. When I fully juice, I extend my legs, extend my core, and that's going to make it so I'm overextended and have a weak position.
metadata.text: **Practice falling safely by rolling onto your back, not by sticking out your limbs, and master controlled bounces, avoiding overextension, as these are crucial foundations for trampoline snowboarding training.**
metadata.videoTitle: Trampoline Basics for Snowboarders | Learn to Tramp Like a Pro – Ep. 1

metadata.text: **Scan and adapt:** Vigorously search for side hits, critically assessing their takeoff, transition, and landing to choose the right approach and speed, and be prepared to improvise.
metadata.videoTitle: Epic Side Hits at Whistler Blackcomb - Perfect Day on Crystal Chair! (RAW)

metadata.text: Maintain a forward, crouched upper body hinge to keep weight balanced for controlled rotations.
metadata.videoTitle: How To "ACTUALLY" Backside 360!

metadata.fullText: Rotate your legs 90 and I want you to literally take your upper body here and try to jump up and counter rotate back facing the camera.
metadata.text: Jump and counter-rotate your upper body to face the camera while rotating your legs 90 degrees.
metadata.videoTitle: Teaching My Sister How to Backside 360 the Right Way (Live Coaching)

metadata.text: Initiate rotations by looking over your shoulder and placing hands on your back hip.
metadata.videoTitle: Teaching My Sister How to Backside 360 the Right Way (Live Coaching)

metadata.text: Focus on rotating your legs 90 degrees while counter-rotating your upper body to face the camera mid-air.
metadata.videoTitle: Teaching My Sister How to Backside 360 the Right Way (Live Coaching)

metadata.text: Evaluate snow conditions to inform your trick choice and execution for a safer experience.
metadata.videoTitle: Breaking Down My Biggest SLAM

metadata.text: Focus on upward lift with your upper body, aiming for a 90-degree chest rotation at takeoff, to maximize pop and enable effective counter-rotation for your frontside 180.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Fix Your Frontside 180s

metadata.fullText: By going and hitting the side of a rail, it stops your sideways momentum and lets you go and fully control the feature. If you don't do this, you're just going to slide off the far side and it's not going to let you lock in. So, every time you're doing a board slide 50/50, even if it's subtle, make sure you're hitting the rail slightly angled towards the side that you're taking off from. A lot of people are scared getting onto rails or board slides, and this makes them go and jump up over the rail, but this is going to disconnect you. What you actually want to do is stay nice and crouch and get onto the rail in this stack position, nice and stable. We don't need to go and pop a lot. We can just stay stable, rotate through, and that'll give us plenty of flow. So stay stable, stay straight, rotate into your board slide. And by going and not adding this up and down plane that lets us enter our boardside position way easier.
metadata.text: **Enter your board slide with a slight angle towards your takeoff side, staying crouched and stable to control your momentum and lock onto the rail.**
metadata.videoTitle: 8 Simple Rail Tips That Make a Huge Difference!

metadata.fullText: So he's setting on multiple ro axis of rotation throughout the spin. This back 12 is more standard. But look at how he keeps his eyes on the landing. So now his lower body, he's rotated like 930, 950, and now he's just letting his lower body continue that rotation as his head stays pointing straight. And that's leaving him in this super, super exaggerated twisted position back uphill. When he twists this much, not only is it making sure that he's spotting blind landing back uphill, what's going to let him diminish his rotational energy, but it's also twisting him, what's making him so he's artificially taller over his snowboard.
metadata.text: **Spot your landing:** Keep your eyes on the landing and let your body rotate naturally, creating an exaggerated twist that helps you see your landing and artificially increases your height over the board.
metadata.videoTitle: How Liam Brearley Uses Counter-Rotation To "DOMINATE"

metadata.text: Spot your landing by keeping your eyes focused on it, which encourages natural body rotation and helps you see the landing.
metadata.videoTitle: How Liam Brearley Uses Counter-Rotation To "DOMINATE"

metadata.text: Rotate your upper body 90 degrees over your front foot to enhance counter-rotation and improve turns.
metadata.videoTitle: How Liam Brearley Uses Counter-Rotation To "DOMINATE"

metadata.text: Focus on the quality of the spin, not just completing the flips.
metadata.videoTitle: Today I Tried My Dream Trick - Japan Vlog 5

metadata.fullText: every turn in snowboarding is based around leverage in order to get a deeper carve you need to increase the leverage on your Edge think of your board as a car jack with your body's purpose to increase the leverage needed to add weight onto your Edge the only difference is you have multiple different ways you can get this leverage when snowboarding and in this video you're going to learn all of them let's start with a classic leaning leaning is when you lean either forward or backwards this adds more pressure onto your Edge by concentrating your weight onto a smaller Point think about it like this The Leverage of holding your board is pretty easy to move when it's like this you can shift it adjust it pretty light but if I go and shift it to the bottom oh that board becomes incredibly heavy and I can't really go and do anything about it this is the same principle we're using when we're leaning on our turns because holding it from the end increases the lever arm making gravity exert more torque so it feels heavier and harder to control this is the same reason leaning adds more pressure to your Edge there are two things to note about leaning one they rely on momentum if you stand still and try to lean you won't get very far before falling forward but you can lean much further when snowboarding this is because speed increases a snowboarder stability due to the way the forcers interact with the board and the snow at higher speeds the board creates more Force against the snow which increases the pressure and enhances the grip this can help the edge of the snowboard dig into the snow offering more stability and traction allowing continue to lean much further than if you weren't moving two the more you lean the more your center of mass is shifted away from your snowboard this makes it so if you hit any icy patch or bump you're much more likely to have your legs kick out from under you resulting in a fall what brings us to the second way to turn your snowboard putting pressure into your boots and bindings since your boots are stiff you can use them to add leverage think about it as using a stick to try leverage a door open because the stick is firm you can add pressure onto one end in order to add leverage to the other your boots and highbacks work in the same way by shifting your knees forward it puts more pressure onto the tops of my boots and because the boots are relatively stiff it adds more pressure to the tow Edge allowing you to increase of amount of edge pressure while keeping your weight over your board for heel side this is where forward lean comes into play forward lean is referring to the angle of your bindings the more forward lean the more leverage you get the faster it is to activate that Leverage so too much will make it so your turns are touchy and not enough will make it so your turns are slower because they have less leverage and activate slower but brings us to number fre opening your hips opening your hips puts pressure onto your Edge by utilizing torsion when I open my hips I push my back toes down as I lift my front toes this makes it so the board warps making it so the back toe Edge digs in as the front of my board is more flat based this lets me hold Edge pressure without my board trying to turn this is why torsion is used a lot on things like back side spins because you want Edge pressure while maintaining a straight line for heel side your front toes go down and your back toes go up this one I find very challenging and lastly we have driving into a turn sometimes called pushing or loading this is a blanket term that's basically referring to using the bend in your legs to increase or decrease the pressure on your Edge as you squat down this condenses your weight and when you condense or load your body weight onto your Edge it increases your Edge pressure and when you stand up or jump it decreases the pressure in your Edge or otherwise known as unweighting your Edge so you load and unload the pressure over your Edge in order to add more traction and decrease your traction the faster you do this motion the more drastic the results this is because the speed of your movement adds Force you're putting into your Edge that's why if you hold yourself in a bent down position it's not going to give you that much extra Edge pressure but as you load into into that position you'll build more and more pressure and as you unwe your Edge it becomes lighter and as you add a little extension or hop into there you get a moment of weightlessness what lets you really swap edges all these techniques work best in correlation of one another because your balance is based on momentum you need to build your momentum before you can get into deeper positions if I try to enter a mad carve right away I won't have enough momentum to hold it but as I get deeper and deeper into my turn it actually accelerates me making me more stable allowing me to get deeper into the turns so when turning follow these steps first set your Edge this can be light I generally use a stack position to get this first bit of edge pressure and from there you can add some lean open the hips load your Edge push into your shins and when you do all these fluently and connected you'll be truly carving like a pro and thank you so much for watching
metadata.text: To achieve deeper carves, increase leverage on your edge by combining leaning, pressing into your boots, opening your hips, and dynamically loading/unloading your legs with momentum.
metadata.videoTitle: 4 Ways to Turn on Your Snowboard (Explained Simply + When to Use Them)

metadata.text: Delay pulling your upper body into the spin until after the board has caught up to generate more rotational power and a flatter axis.

metadata.fullText: all of rail riding is based off of one principle that principle being you want to maintain a stack position as consistently as possible throughout the full duration of the feature this is because when you're stacked over your board maintaining the same balance point you won't have any risk of slipping out or going and flopping around the issue comes from every single thing you do on a rail will try to break this position if you do a backside board slide you're going and popping up what's going to try break your position counter rotating what's going to shift your position so we need to go and accommodate for that in order to do this we do a bunch of pre- steps and have a bunch of little subtle techniques making it so it's way easier to hold a stack position increase a range of motion without going in overextending and compromising it so that's what we're going to cover in this video all the little tricks and tips that Pro snowers use in order to make rails simplified easier to approach and much safer and more consistent so let's get right into it first let's quickly break down what a stack position is a stack position is referring to your balanced position that you can go go and move your full range up and down sideways back and forth whatever while maintaining your center of balance over your board so here because I'm using my stack position principles I'm able to go and Crouch down infinite that's because I'm keeping my weight set over the balls my feet so that's what's letting me go and squat down this much if we go and look at something like a 50/50 with a more proper form we'll see that it's a lot more subtle I'm just going and making sure that my legs have a little bit of Bend we need a little bit of Bend in our legs metadata.text: **Maintain a "stack position" over your board by keeping your weight balanced over the balls of your feet, allowing for controlled movement and stability on rails.**
metadata.videoTitle: The “CRUCIAL” Techniques Pros Use On Every Rail In The Park

metadata.text: Proper stacking improves your ability to initiate and control your slides.
metadata.videoTitle: The “CRUCIAL” Techniques Pros Use On Every Rail In The Park

metadata.text: When spinning, keep your head stationary and rotate your upper body, finishing with a counter-rotation to exit the spin.
metadata.videoTitle: Learn From The Pros - Hiroto Ogiwara Snowboarding Breakdown

metadata.fullText: I'm holding this position. Then as I go and get onto the rail, look at my upper body. Look at how stationary it is. Look at how smooth it is. And I'm landing in pretty much exactly the same position that I took off in. Still a bit of bend in the legs. Still hinge forward. And still keeping my center of balance over the balls of my feet. This is the key to doing front side 50/50s safely and smoothly. And that is taking off in a position that's very similar to the position you want to be in on the rail.
metadata.text: Maintain a stable, hinged upper body and balanced stance over the balls of your feet throughout your approach and onto the rail for a smooth frontside 50/50.
metadata.videoTitle: The Technique Pros Use for Effortless Rails

metadata.text: Maintain a slight bend in your legs and use your arms and chest to initiate rotation instead of fully extending your legs at takeoff.
metadata.videoTitle: Live Coaching: Backside Rotations Made Easy

metadata.text: To generate spin power, exaggerate sinking into your heel edge, push your back hip out, and extend your legs to create a stable platform.
metadata.videoTitle: This Summer Training Unlocks Backside 720s

metadata.text: Focusing on upper body rotation is crucial for executing advanced maneuvers like Miller flips.
metadata.videoTitle: ￼Trying To Understand WTF Happened at XGames Knuckle Huck 2025

metadata.text: Delaying your edge change helps build rotational momentum for frontside spins.
metadata.videoTitle: The #1 Mistake On Frontside Spins (And How to Fix It Fast)

metadata.fullText: So, most of your power here isn't being used for rotation and instead is being set down to the ground. And this is why your rotation is being cut short. So you're going and snapping your spin and then you're holding it in this downward arc. Because if you actually tried to follow through and throw snap your spin like I'm doing here on this angle, you would be going and throwing yourself straight front flip. And that's why we really need to get you taller because you're just not going to be able to put power into this position. So that's your issue. You're coming in, your setup carve isn't putting you in a position where you can get tall, open your hips, open your chest, and this is making you go and crunch over, lean forward, and as you try to add more power to your spin, your upper body is too hinged forward, causing too much of your momentum to be angled downwards. And this is causing you to get too flippy. And this too flippy of axis is making it so you can't hold the constant spot on the knuckle and then go and hold that rotation and pull all the way through. To fix this, first you need to practice at home. I want you to practice going and loading your weight onto your heel edge, opening your hips, opening your chest preemptively towards the corner of a jump and visualizing that you're looking at the corner of a jump. By angling our whole bo body towards the corner, it lets our hips open up more, our chest open up more, and that's going to give us more range of motion to play with.
metadata.text: **Get taller and open your hips and chest towards the corner of the jump before spinning to avoid falling forward and ensure a consistent, powerful rotation.**
metadata.videoTitle: 80% Of Riders Make This Mistake On Backside Spins - Video Analysis

metadata.text: Maintain a balanced, centered stance directly over your snowboard to navigate unpredictable conditions.
metadata.videoTitle: Stop Slipping Out: How To Ride ICE With Confidence

metadata.text: Use an airbag for a safe, low-cost environment to learn and practice new snowboarding tricks, allowing you to experiment with techniques and build confidence before taking them to snow.

metadata.fullText: And the really key thing about this board is first, it's full camber. You want all of your park boards to be full camber. This is because full camber goes and helps you grip the snow, gives you the most power. Uh when I first moved to Whistler and I was trying to ask my coach, ask people what to buy. We're like, all the companies make really great boards. Just make sure you're getting full camber just because it's the best shape for the jumps. And if you're trying to go and push yourself as a freestyle rider and you want to get the most out of your board, full camber is really the way to go. So that's the first requirement that I needed to try this board in the first place. But I also tried the Team what's like the less pro variant of the Team Pro. And the big difference between the two and is actually the biggest selling point for the Team Pro is how it feels. The Team feels a lot like a Burton Custom where you can really feel that wooden core. It feels snappy. It feels tangy. and you can feel the power. The Pro is even more stiff, but it feels not like it. So, even though it gives you all the same amount of pop, it gives you all the same amount of tang, it gives it to you in a more adjustable way. I like comparing it to like sort of how plastic flexes, uh, compared to how wood flexes, where wood's really hard and it snaps back really aggressively. Plastic sort of comes up, molds a little bit, and drops a little bit slower. So, it's not quite as snappy, quite as responsive, but it makes up for that with consistency and precision. And this is something I've only experienced on the Team Pro in a way that I actually found really beneficial. Uh it feels a lot like a pro riders uh custom board that the company's making for them, but you're getting it just from the factory store.
metadata.text: For park riding, choose a full camber board for superior snow grip, power, and responsiveness, especially for jumps.
metadata.videoTitle: Is The TEAM PRO Right For You? Honest Board Review

metadata.text: Practice a stacked, neutral body position, then shift weight to the back leg and twist the upper body forward for dynamic movements.
metadata.videoTitle: Why Riding Centred Is Holding You Back (and How to Fix It)

metadata.text: Focus on building foundational skills, like proper stance and form, for larger tricks.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Choose Your Perfect Snowboard Stance! Every Stance in Action

metadata.text: Engage your core and maintain a straight posture for a clean pop and to avoid a 'dumpy' feeling.
metadata.videoTitle: Instantly Improve Your 360s With These Small but Game-Changing Tips!

metadata.fullText: Um backside 360 is probably just the trick I teach the most. So, we'll use this one. So, on a backside 360, what are the keys to success? The keys to success are a good takeoff, a little bit of continued rotation with that upper body, and then pulling through with that head. So, then you can go and see that landing and use counter rotation to finish it if needed. So when I'm visualizing a backside 360, I'm first going to go and visualize that setup card. I like using a little bit of body motions when I'm doing this. So I'll go and practice with my body heel side, toe side, wind up, snap, rotate, rotate, rotate. Then I'll go and close my eyes and try to visualize those muscle movements, those feelings with the trick. So now I'm going to go and think about it. So like heel side, toe side, pop, look, carry. And this is really powerful training because not only are we training how we think the trick should look, we're also training how we think the trick should feel. And let me tell you, this works really well. I'll give you an example. I was learning cab dub 9ines on airbag in Japan. And I've never tried a cab dub 9. It's not something I'm really comfortable with. I'm not much of a flipper. But when I went and actually tried this trick, I was blown away. It felt exactly like I was picturing it, exactly like I was envisualizing it. And all the worries I had about the trick didn't turn out to be true. And I was able to throw it. And as soon as I threw it and pulled into that second flip, I'm like, I got this.
metadata.text: Visualize and mentally rehearse your backside 360 by practicing body movements and focusing on the feeling of the takeoff, upper body rotation, and head movement to improve execution.
metadata.videoTitle: My Snowboard Mental Training Advice!

metadata.fullText: comes in from a transition, neutally sets his upper body back to that neutral spot, but a little bit more. He's actively opening his chest 90° here. Why is he doing this? It's because as you come off a jump, your legs will naturally want to sync up with your upper body. And because he's trying to rotate and hit this angle in the other way, he can't really pop up and try to use a spin that creates momentum. So, what does he do instead? He preemptively sets his upper body in the position it wants to be in. So then the legs can come and meet it. Let's look for this one. His shoulder here is a little bit closed. Chest is honestly a little bit open, but hip squared. And look at this front knee is sort of closed off. So he's popping up. And this is a small enough angle that he's able to go and shift. And we can see that he might have wanted to close it a little bit more because he had to use a little bit of arm to redirect.
metadata.text: **Preemptively open your chest 90° away from your rotation direction before takeoff to allow your legs to catch up and facilitate a cleaner spin.**
metadata.videoTitle: FUNDAMENTALS Pushed To The Max And what you can learn from it!

metadata.fullText: If you go and have your arm come downwards into the it's going to do this. And I see that a lot when people are trying to learn these tricks is we're going and letting the shoulders dip towards the ground. This happens more on a snowboard because you're on that edge. And when you're on that edge, you try to throw that spin and that's going to throw you downwards. So when we're doing this, make sure that you're holding your neutral position, but you're not letting your shoulders drop down. Our chest is still up and we're throwing on that nice strong plane here.
metadata.text: Maintain an upright, neutral body position with your chest up, avoiding dropping your shoulders downwards when initiating spins to prevent falling off balance.
metadata.videoTitle: The Secret To Spinning Like A Pro! – Core Moves Every Snowboarder Needs - EP 4

metadata.fullText: So this ollie is pretty interesting because it's off a very like steep point. So it's not much of a surface to go and generate pop off of. So in order to go and get max power, he's doing something interesting. He's first preemptively setting all of his weight onto his front foot. See how he's completely leaned over there. And normally for an ollie, you think you want to like shift everything back, but here he's just going and kicking his hips back, but while keeping his upper body in the same neutral position. This is because this little transition here uh is so short. You don't actually have enough time to do do a full range of motion. So, he's going keeping his upper body in the position it needs to be for the landing and that needs to be for like the start of a takeoff and then relying on the hips and putting pressure off that tail. And I really want to note power on your oies comes from maximizing your surface area, maximizing that time your board's making contact with the lip. So just by going and pushing his board into his lip, it's already naturally putting himself a whole board length in the air. And that's before getting that little bit of pop. And now watch how his tail pops through the lip of a takeoff and then springs up. So you're not trying to spring up before the takeoff or off the takeoff. You're trying to push through that takeoff and rely on the snap to pull you up. And as he's doing this, he's keeping his upper body over. And because he wants to do this a little bit of a shifty, what does he do? He does a preemptive motion of opening his chest towards the jump. And that's why he's completely 90 here. So that way he comes up, does his little shifty, and because his upper body was set in that neutral position, already set for the landing, he naturally comes into that landing just perfectly. When you see people landing tail heavy like this, especially prolevel riders like Tru Smith, it's not because their weight set over their tail, uh, it's because their weight set centered and they're just tilting their hips towards that tail. And that's why he's able to go and hit that tail and then snap it down. So whenever you see like a red Gerard hitting with that tail first, it's not because they're going and landing tail heavy. They're just going and shifting their hips so that tail goes and lands first. Uh what's way better, if you land tail heavy consistently, you're going to snap your boards. This hit here is really interesting because look at how bad this takeoff is. It's sort of indebted, groomed, and he's trying to travel very straight. If he travels too far to the left, he won't have enough uh speed to go and do the line he's trying to do and hit that sharpened feature.
metadata.text: To maximize ollie power off steep or short takeoffs, shift weight forward, kick hips back while keeping upper body neutral, and push your tail through the lip to utilize the board's snap.
metadata.videoTitle: How @truthdsmith Gets Massive POP – Snowboarding Breakdown

metadata.fullText: So right here, he's basically already in the exact same position. Then what does he do? because he's over the rail and he has a bit of sideways momentum, he bashes in that blunt slide, killing that sideways momentum. And that's why he's able to lock in so good. And then when he's getting this pop out here, what does he do? He goes and make sure that this uh this part of his board's lifting up so it doesn't clip the rail and this part of the board's pushing down, making maximum contact. And that's why he's getting this such good pop because he blunted. He loaded a lot of pressure onto this edge. And as he goes and snaps off the end, that's giving him good air time. Just by not letting your legs go and sogg get absorbed, you're going to get so much power. And now this is the last one and honestly the one I'm least qualified to talk about, so we'll keep it a little shorter. But here, he's preemptly setting his weight onto that front foot. So see how his body's preemptively moved. Now all he needs to do is pop up into this position. And now his weight is already set there. And this is just a matter of commitment.
metadata.text: To execute a smooth blunt slide and maximize pop, kill sideways momentum by absorbing it into the slide, then load pressure onto your edge and snap off the rail by lifting your tail while pressing your nose down.
metadata.videoTitle: How @truthdsmith Gets Massive POP – Snowboarding Breakdown

metadata.fullText: When I'm doing a rail like this, I don't have the expectation of making it to the end every time, but I'm making sure my upper body is coming forward, hips going back, keeping my center of balance over top of my snowboard. So, even if I do slip out left side or right side, I can go with that momentum. The reason why it's so important to maintain bend in the legs and bend in the upper body is because it gives you the ability to move your legs independently to your torso and that's going to give you all the micro control. So here I'm maintaining a strong bent position my legs popping up and maintaining basically the same exact position throughout the feature and that lets me go and extend out of it comfortably at the end. So again at any point here because I'm in a balanced strong position I could go and jump off my back foot to the right or to the left. And that way if I feel that I'm slipping out I have the ability to go and dismount the rail and I'm not locked in. Because the biggest misconception I see people have on rails is thinking it's a balancing task. Really, rails, balancing doesn't matter at all. If you get a good enough takeoff and you hit the rail properly, you're locked in from the start. It's when we start trying to reposition, pull our upper body one way or the other that we start compromising ourselves. And that can lead to some serious slip outs. So, whenever we're hitting rails, the goal is to take off in a position that's almost identical to the position we want to be on the rail.
metadata.text: Maintain a bent, balanced stance with your upper body forward and hips back, allowing independent leg movement and the ability to adjust and dismount safely if you lose balance.
metadata.videoTitle: Watch This Before Your First 50-50s!

metadata.text: To improve your frontside 360s and grab consistency, focus on a cleaner, more powerful approach with a solid toe edge transition, delaying your upper body rotation until takeoff to maximize pop and control.
metadata.videoTitle: Start Grabbing Your Frontside 360s with these Small Changes

metadata.fullText: All you need to do is make sure your back hand is pulled around your body. So, as soon as you feel your hands come slide off the end of the takeoff, take your arm and pull it around the body straight back to this position where it's slightly leading the spin. Let's go through that one more time because this is really where the magic is made. So, you come in, extend your legs into that downward dog. Rotate your hands facing back uphill, shoulders squared, back straight, head looking down towards the landing. As soon as you feel your hands come off a takeoff, take your back arm and pull it around. This is going to go and make it so your axis of rotation gets pulled back down to center and is what's going to let you get your feet back under you. If you don't pull with your back arm, you're not going to continue that rotation and you're not going correct your axis. That's why this trick is really flexible, but you need to make sure that you're holding this strong camera facing position and then pulling with your arm. From there, it's just like a normal 360. You should be able to fully see the landing and just keep pulling up that arm and that's going to rebalance you, taking you into the landing. So, recap, do your setup carve, getting your toe edge, not too soon. And as you go and reach for the ground, go and make it so your fingers are pointing back towards the camera.
metadata.text: After leaving the takeoff, actively pull your back arm around your body to re-center your rotation and prepare for landing.
metadata.videoTitle: How to Backside Miller Flip 360 (The Most Popular Knuckle Trick!)

metadata.fullText: If you're buying a board that fits you, then reference stance should be pretty close to what you want with like one or two notches back and forth, flexibility being reasonable. But maxing out your stance or making it too narrow is going to be one of the biggest things you can do to hold back your riding. So, when in doubt, reference it out. When you buy a new snowboard, you actually want to wax it one to three times. And that means complete wax, complete scrape. This is because the wax they come with isn't very good and it's not going to really protect the base. So, taking that extra time to wax your board even before the first day is going to really increase the longevity. For edges though, if you want to go and get on your board and instantly hit a front side board slide on a sticky rail, you could consider grinding them down. Personally, I've been riding for a long time and I haven't ground down my edges for 8 years and it hasn't been a problem. If you just take a few laps, do some carving, do some railing, what I'd recommend on a new board, the edges will be good to go.
metadata.text:
**Dial in your stance:** Start with the reference stance and make minor adjustments; avoid extremes.
*   **Wax your new board:** Apply 1-3 full wax jobs and scrapes before riding for better base protection and longevity.
metadata.videoTitle: The Simplest Snowboard Buying Guide (No BS, No Sponsers)

metadata.fullText: So, if I'm coming to a rail stack, low down, but I'm trying to go and pop up into a different position, it's going to be out of whack. So, I want to try to go and maintain the most constant rail, as little extra movement in positions as possible. And this will let me go and just feel in control. So for here, just keeping straight, a little bit of a down rail like this. I'm setting a little bit of an angle, nice position, coasting off, and trying to do as little extra movement as possible. Snowboarding is all about minimizing your movements. The more you go and minimize the movement coming into a feature, the less you'll need to do, letting you go and focus on those fundamentals and get control, and it's going to greatly increase your rail potential on every feature. Who doesn't like a good shifty on their snowboard?
metadata.text: **Minimize body movement on rails:** Stay low and in a consistent, stable position to maintain control and maximize your rail potential.
metadata.videoTitle: 10 Park Tips Every Snowboarder Should Know!

metadata.text: To initiate a strong ollie, transfer weight to your back foot while keeping your back straight and upper body centered.
metadata.videoTitle: How To Ollie The Right Way, So You Can Stay In The Air All Day.

metadata.fullText: But how do we train this? And how do we utilize it? Instead of thinking about riding like this, I want to have my hips slightly more open because that makes it so it's easier to sink towards that back leg. Try this at home. Just be in this position. See how hard it is to sink to the back and then pull forward. Or if we just open those hips a little bit, it's a lot easier to get this control and get this pop while keeping this hinge forward. And this is going to be the serious key is unlocking a riding position that you like taking off, extending, being in the air controlled, and also being in the landing. Because I ride in a position that's so applicable to jumping, it comes naturally to me.
metadata.text: Open your hips slightly to make it easier to sink into your back leg, improving control for takeoffs, air time, and landings.
metadata.videoTitle: 90% of Snowboarders Are Jumping Wrong (Here's Why)

metadata.text: Initiate the spin with weight slightly on your back foot, focusing on smooth energy transfer.
metadata.videoTitle: How To "ACTUALLY" Backside 360!

metadata.text: Consider boot stiffness; extremely stiff boots may cause discomfort and pain, preventing enjoyable riding, especially in powder.
metadata.videoTitle: Snowboard Boot Guide: How To Find The Perfect Fit!

metadata.fullText: The next thing we want to do is make sure that we're lifting our upper body and having our arms come up and pushing through that jump, making it so most of our energy is being used to lift. Think about it as doing a straight air. We're hitting like a side hit. We're trying to go and use our body to put us up, not across. Because on a front side 180, you really can just do this all of counter rotation if your upper body is in the right position. So, let's look at Torstein here. Coming in heel edge, closing off, not holding it too long, just being really patient and getting into it, getting maximum extension. An important thing I'll note here is Torstein's extending as much as you'd ever want to. And look at how serious the angle of his board is. This is pushing the pop. So, this is the goal, but not where you want to start because that makes the margin for error much, much smaller. But as you pop, you want to make sure that you're going and lifting your chest up and try to have it rotate around 90°. This is the sweet point because it makes it so you can utilize counter rotation as soon as you bring your legs up, even when you're bringing them up. So that's what Torstein's doing here. Upper body 90, bringing the legs right up to his chest and activating counter rotation. From this position, he's now on the arc of the jump because he got a good takeoff, his weight set over his toes, and he's dispersed most of his rotational energy by having it mostly sent up in the first place, and then using counter rotation, what will diminish his maximum rotation velocity.
metadata.text: **Focus on upward lift with your upper body, aiming for a 90-degree chest rotation at takeoff, to maximize pop and enable effective counter-rotation for your frontside 180.**
metadata.videoTitle: How To Fix Your Frontside 180s

metadata.text: Absorb impact upon landing by squatting low on your toe edge and shifting to a balanced stance over the balls of your feet.
metadata.videoTitle: How Liam Brearley Uses Counter-Rotation To "DOMINATE"

metadata.text: Visualize the entire trick beforehand to mentally prepare and execute the movements more effectively.

metadata.text: Improve versatility by practicing switch frontside and backside rotations.
