metadata.fullText: And that's how you can get like those overshifties and just get into back more back board more consistently. Because if you're in the middle of your board, you can't shift out your back leg to get it more tweaked because you're too connected. So when you're doing these motions, try focus on landing of the front foot a little bit. You don't need to hyper exaggerate it if it's tiring you out because this is all just a process. The next thing we need to do is backside board slides have a heelside approach. When you're going on your heel side, in order to keep your weight set towards the balls of your feet, you need to really go and exaggerate your upper body positioning. If I'm in my like normal boardside position and I go and try to pop into the back board, it's going to really straighten me. So, the solution for this is adding more bend to her legs. So, when you're practicing this, add more bend. And this bend will make it so when you pop up, you're not fully extending. See how I'm popping up and keeping a little bit of bend in my legs. This is letting me keep my upper body forward, letting me counter rotate.
metadata.text: **For backside board slides, exaggerate upper body forward and add more bend to your knees upon popping to maintain balance and counter-rotation, while landing slightly front-footed helps with tweaking.**
metadata.videoTitle: The Key Movements Behind Backside Boardslides - And How To Train Them! (No Gear Needed)

metadata.fullText: Think about a Japanese euro carver getting down low. This is going to set a lot of weight onto our heel edge, making it so we can hold that heel edge pressure without needing to lean. If you're leaning on your heel edge, when you go to switch to your toe edge, you're also leaning, making it way harder to time. So, we want to drop low enough, hip here, hand over here, so our hips are open, our weights on our heels, and then when we go and get through the spoon of the jump, wait until you're getting through the spoon. Then slightly slightly lessen lessen lessen until you're tall. And once you're tall, now push out the hips. And a big thing people do here that really throws them off is we'll go from this position up and then try wind up overextending your core. We don't need a big motion. And actually the best riders in the world are letting their hands just come out straight from this spot. So I want you to practice this. Get on your heel edge.
metadata.text: **Get low on your heel edge to engage it without leaning, which sets you up for a smoother transition to your toe edge.**
metadata.videoTitle: The Best Way to Train Backside Spins This Summer (No Gear Needed)

metadata.fullText: In this video, I'm going to teach you how you can train your front side board slides off the mountain. But first, let's break down what makes this trick work. There is three fundamental body motions that you need to unlock before taking your front side board slide to snow. The first is being able to do your full motion while maintaining your center of balance over the balls of your feet. This goes and lets you stay balanced on the rail and makes it so you're way less susceptible to go and fall backwards or forwards. Next is maintaining a little bit of hinge in the hips and a little bit of bend in the legs. This lets you go and fully utilize the rotation in your torso, your hips, allowing you to get your board into that 90° position. Lastly, you need to do all these movements while keeping your head as stationary as possible. If you have your head going up, down, moving all over, it's going to throw off your whole center of balance. So, you want to go and do this whole motion while keeping your eyes and head locked in the most similar position possible. That said, this trick is ridiculously challenging to learn. It took me many years. is I was trying dub back 10s, landing double wildats and making finals at the national level before I could do a proper front side board slide. So, let me tell you, I understand the struggles of this trick, and I understand how hard it can be. And these summer training routines, this kind of way of thinking about it is really what helped me make the breakthrough and made it so I could start lacing this trick. So, a big issue people have is two front. First, they go and try to pop onto the rail. This fully extends them, making them tall and moves their center balance from their balls of their feet over to their heels. Next, they try to do way too big of a position of counter rotation. This collapses the side, compromises the body, and makes it so you're just you're in a sketchy spot.
metadata.text: Maintain balance on your feet, a slight bend in your knees and hips, and a stationary head to achieve the necessary rotation and board position for a frontside board slide.

metadata.text: Focus on mastering a straight, tall backside 360 takeoff by delaying your edge engagement and lifting your chest, as this is the foundation for all backside spins.

You want a little bit of angle of your board towards that right corner because it's going to increase your turn radius making it so it's harder to drift. If you go straight from heel edge to toe edge, you're going to be able to come off completely straight. So having this little bit of angle towards the corner of the jump really lets you smooth it out. But the less angle you have, the slower you can do the transition and the less geforce you have. If you're traversing across the slope, well, switching edges like this, it's going to be impossible not to be leaned forward.
metadata.text: Maintain a slight board angle towards the corner of the jump on your edge before the jump to increase your turn radius, prevent drifting, and smooth your transition onto the jump.

metadata.fullText: Basically, trying to get my screws as tight as possible. If your bindings get loose or you didn't do the screws on right enough, this is what's going to happen. metadata.text: Separate upper and lower body and keep your chest hinged forward for controlled rotation.

metadata.text: Keep your balance centered over your feet during slides by maintaining a strong, tall back and keeping your 'nipples over your knees'.

metadata.fullText: This makes it so as we go and do our two-footed jump, we maintain a little bit of tail pressure. Basically lets us get the same benefits of an ollie but without all that extra body dynamics of trying to get that motion because if you start front foot, shift to the back foot, try to get that ollie a little too complex. So I'm preemptively shifting my hips to the back foot, pulling my upper body forward, hands forward. So then when I go and pop up, my weight gets slightly shifted towards that front foot. And here you can see it's still completely in line, completely straight, and I'm just slowly shifting those weight to the front foot. And then at this position right here, because I maintain tail pressure, my board's naturally over top of the feature. And because I'm fine hanging at slightly angled, alls I need to do is utilize a little bit of counter rotation. The key to this is stability. We want the head in one position, the chest in one position, and we don't really want it lifting up or going down. Instead, we want a comfortable enough position that we can hold this and then just counter rotate through it, staying as still as possible. Because if we go and start adding a bunch of dynamics, it's going to make it a lot harder to control. One of the biggest mistakes you'll see on front side board slides is this, and that's just staying too tall and extended. The reason why this is problematic is look at how much he's struggling to get that board slide completely 90 and he doesn't really have much balance. When you're completely vertical like this, there's two major downsides. First of all, you can't really pull your hips back and pull your upper body forward to rebalance. So, it's all based on leaning. And when you're leaning from a tall position, even a little bit of angle will put a lot of your weight away from your snowboard, making it way more likely that you'll slip out one way or the other. So, you don't have flexibility.

metadata.fullText: And we're sort of trying to get this rock motion. When you're doing this, try to not let your legs overextend out of your body. And try to not ever go completely tall and lifted in this direction. Get your weight set on the balls of your feet. Shift it back slightly. And as you extend, have your upper body concave forward. If you do that and train that consistently, when you go to try these straighters again, they're going to feel so, so much better.
metadata.text: Maintain a bent-leg, "rock" motion with your weight on the balls of your feet and your upper body leaning forward to improve straighter landings.
metadata.videoTitle: Improving Your Straight Airs

metadata.fullText: It's this athletic stance here. So, this is actually the most important premotion that you can have for every turn into every maneuver because you're going to go and end in it, ride in it, transition through it. Just by maintaining that little bit of hinge forward, that little bit of bending your legs, you're going to be set up so much more powerful to go and get any carbs. And when I'm going to try to do these carves steeper, more aggressive, what I'm doing is I'm just going and extending this more. So to demonstrate this, look at this position here. Stacked a little bit leaned. This is over the heel edge. So I need to have my butt further down and my upper body a bit further forward. And then instead of trying to go and change my form, alls I'm doing is trying and keep that ma same balance point as I squat down. So as I squat lower, my upper body comes more forward. And this brings us to another really important rule for carving. And that is the deeper your turn, the faster you're turning, the more momentum and grip you're going to have. I don't have the scientific principle on the top of my head why this works, but that's just something to note. The faster you're going, the more you'll have balance. And this is why you can do go and do like lean turns. This is why you can lean further on a snowboard than you can just standing.
metadata.text: **Maintain an athletic, slightly forward-hinged stance with bent knees, keeping your upper body stacked and forward over your board as you squat lower for deeper, more aggressive turns and increased grip.**

metadata.text: Maintain an athletic stance with bent legs for jumps, avoiding deep squats to improve control.

metadata.videoTitle: The “CRUCIAL” Techniques Pros Use On Every Rail In The Park

metadata.fullText: We want to be taking slight heel pressure towards the feature, but we don't want to be taking off with our weight set over our heels. So, in order to counter this, we want to pull our upper body forward a lot. The idea behind this is you want to go and deconstruct your rail position. So, here my rail position, leg bent, upper body over, and figure out how we can go and get into this position with as few movements as possible. For that, we want to cut out as many variables as possible. So, what do we need for a backside board slide? Really, we don't really need to drift onto the feature because just by going and keeping our board relatively close to the feature, maintaining tail contact, we can go and counter rotate and our foot will be naturally over the rail. We want to go and do our board side set either over our front foot or back foot because it gives us more room to go and kick out one foot. Way easier to get into the 90.
metadata.text: Lean your upper body forward significantly to deconstruct your rail position, maintaining tail contact and keeping your board close to the feature for a smoother board slide entry.
metadata.videoTitle: STOP SLIPPING OUT ON BOARD-SLIDES!

My legs should be much straighter because if you have this much bend in your legs, you have to go and have your upper body come forward in order to compensate for it. So my legs in all of my spins for this season were too bent starting. And that's making it so as I go and throw, look at how my hands touching my board, I'm completely broken at the waist. This is going to still happen sometimes if your legs are straight, but it's going to happen pretty much every time if your legs a little bit more bent. metadata.fullText: The reason why you want a wide board is because a toe hang. If you're on too narrow of a board for your boot length, you're going to get something called toe drag. That's where your toes are hanging off the end. And you'll get something called heel drag. That's where your heels hanging off the end. This makes it so as you rail the turn, your boot actually hits the snow. And it really limits how deep you can get into your turns. So, if your foot's bigger than a 10, I'd highly recommend looking into getting a wide snowboard. The downside to using a wide snowboard on more narrow feet is it's going to make it so your board's less responsive because your pressure points are going to be set further away from the edge, slowing down your turns. That's why on something like this, a wider board doesn't really matter because it's a POW board, so your turns are slow, flowy anyway. But if you're trying to have like a high performance park board, you want to make sure you're getting a board that fits the length of your feet as close as possible. And I'm sorry for anyone of solid size 12, size 13 ft. They really don't make boards wide enough for you guys. And you're always going to have a little bit of that toe and heel drag.
metadata.text: If your boots are size 10 or larger, opt for a wide snowboard to prevent toe and heel drag, which impedes deep carving and can cause your boots to hit the snow.

metadata.fullText: For this episode, we're going to focus on one of the most important aspects of trampolining and snowboarding, and that is counter rotation. Counter rotation is when you lead a rotation of your upper body and then pull it back across your body in order to come back into a neutral position. You can think about this as like wrapping up a towel. You wrap it up, let it go, and it whips back to the other place. So, we're going and building tension in our core, and then when we go and pop up, that tension will naturally want to decrease. And then when we go and counter it and pull the arms the other way, it's going to rotate us. Counter rotation is really useful all the way up to 270 degrees of rotation. And this is going to make it so it's way easier to learn a trick.
metadata.text: **Build rotational tension in your core and lead with your upper body, then actively counter-rotate your arms to control your spin and land tricks more easily.**

Being completely stiff and center like this is really hard to move around. But as soon as I go and shift this to my back leg and twist my upper body and pull it forward, I now can get myself so much lower towards the ground while maintaining these same principles. A big thing that people get confused on this is the difference between leaning and hip shifting. So here's leaning. I have my whole body leaned over my back foot. And you can tell I'm in this position because I can easily lift this leg. But through just hip shifts, I'm coming down stacked neutral position, pulling the hips back, taking my upper body forward. And now I can still lift my front leg, but I'm not able to hold it up there balanced. I have to use my core. This is giving me the 60% of weight on back leg, 40% on front leg. And from here, as I want to increase my range of motion, increase my squat, I shift back more and more and more, letting my upper body rotate more in correlation. And this is how we go in flow through these turns. When I'm doing a jump, if I have my hip shifted back, upper body forward, when I pop up, it's going to make it so my back leg extends, front leg stays a little bit nicer, and that's going to naturally put me into this ollie that goes and comes back centered. We do this with a trick, say a backside 180, it's going to make it so I can just pop up and rotate super clean.

Uh, and that's why when you rotate, you're coming in and everything's all connected. So, the issue here is because you're rotating your whole rotation completely connected, you're not going to have any micro control or adjustment. So, if you snap your rotation too hard off the takeoff, you're going to over rotate. If you snap it too soft, you're going to under rotate. So, the solution for this is what we call disconnection, where we disconnect our lower body and upper body slightly. So instead of going and snapping here, connecting everything tight and pulling it in and trying to rotate together, instead I'm snapping here and then my upper body keeps going and only once my upper body's here, then my tail takes off, then I connect it. So then everything's stacked here and that lets me take my upper body's energy and channel it and pulling through. So the difference is as soon as you're hitting neutral with your upper body, you're now ro you're rotating with your hips, rotating with your knee, and continuing it. And that's what's causing the pre- spin. But what you want to be doing is having a slight separation of the upper and lower body. So as you rotate past this point, your upper body keeps rotating, but your legs are still staying straight, popping off the jump.
metadata.text:
**For frontside 360s, visualize a hardway takeoff by being on your toes, then shift to your heels to pop up, ensuring you stay over your board for more power and a corked spin.**
*   **For backside 360s, intentionally disconnect your upper and lower body during the rotation, allowing your upper body to continue rotating past neutral before engaging your legs to complete the spin with better control.**

metadata.fullText: So, for a dub back 10, the key to success is pulling your head into a second part of a flip. So, what I'll do for my mental training on this trick is I'll go and practice my wind up snap and then pulling in. I'm trying to really memorize this motion right here because that's going to be what pulls me into the second part of the flip. And whenever you're doing a trick in snowboarding, there's going to be a big leap of faith of like, will this actually work? Will this give me enough power? And that's even more true on doubles. So that's what we're trying to go and figure out and really unlock in the mind is how can we go and get this motion and get reassured that the trick's going to be success as early on as possible. Because if you're just throwing a backside 720, when you're learning it, your spot probably isn't going to be too locked in. So, there's going to be a moment of unknown and that moment of unknown can really mess up your whole form. So, we want to be able to go and use our visualization so we can go and train our takeoffs, train every part of the trick so we feel confident throughout that first portion of the trick. Then, we spot for the landing and we're like, "Okay, we do got this. So, let me go and hit that other mental training and pull in." And this video will go and lead into the fear that comes into it because ideally, you're doing your visualization detailed enough and realistic enough. that's triggering that fear sense in your brain, that little bit of anxiety that hits your chest. I remember many nights countless where I've been was visualizing my tricks and I'd get myself so scared I wasn't able to sleep. And this is actually the feeling that we really want to get comfortable in because I don't care how good you get at snowboarding, how much you shred. You're never going to get rid of that feeling.
metadata.text: Practice the "wind-up snap and pull-in" motion to mentally prepare for the second rotation of a dub back 10, visualizing the entire trick to build confidence and overcome the fear of the unknown.

metadata.text: Focus on mastering fundamental techniques like maintaining speed, keeping knees bent, and proper body positioning on smaller features before attempting advanced tricks on larger terrain to prevent injuries and mental blocks.
metadata.videoTitle: I Made These Mistakes So You Don’t Have To! - EP 2

metadata.fullText: But the guys who have mastered it sure make front side spinning look a lot of fun. So with that out of the way, let's rank them. Flat spins, I'd give this third spot. Super consistent, super safe. Anyone who's a casual rider, you're not a gymnast, this is such a good way to do it. And it's really fun.
metadata.text: **Master flat spins first:** They are a consistent, safe, and fun way to start spinning, ideal for casual riders.
metadata.videoTitle: Why Pro Snowboarders Spin Frontside in Different Ways

metadata.fullText: And to do this, we go and keep tail pressure and just try to use something called a pop. The pop goes and gets you up and over the rail with as little impact as possible. So, whenever you're hitting a rail, go and make sure you're not alling and you're getting onto that rail as a little extra height because that's going to make it so your impact's minimal, letting you go and walk into a rail much easier with way lower chance of picking out and getting hurt. Boxes are smooth, non-grippy surfaces. So, when you do a 50/50 on them, it's really hard to be in control and balance.
metadata.text: **Apply tail pressure for a pop before hitting a rail to get extra height, minimize impact, and improve control.**
metadata.videoTitle: 10 Park Tips Every Snowboarder Should Know!

metadata.text: Look through the end of the rail to maintain control and power through your exit.
metadata.videoTitle: 10 Park Tips Every Snowboarder Should Know!

metadata.fullText: If I try to throw a spin with full extending up, it's going to completely throw me out of whack. That's why we can go and use these big bounces to generate height, but when we're doing our actual tricks, we want to maintain our balance over the balls of our feet. So, when you're bouncing, you're not fully extending everything straight. Instead, you're keeping a little bit of hinge in the upper body, a little bit of bend in your legs, and this lets you rotate over the balls of your feet, and that's going to give you a lot more similar uh bounce and rotation access that you'll find on a snowboard. And the next thing we're going to do is just not over bounce. We don't want to be bouncing all over the trampoline and then trying to do our tricks because it's going to throw us off. So, I recommend using the free or four bounce system. That's why you just start flat and you go one, two, three, throwing your trick on the third bounce.
metadata.text: **Maintain balance over the balls of your feet with bent knees and a slightly hinged upper body for controlled rotation, using only a few controlled bounces (e.g., the 3-bounce system) to initiate your tricks.**
metadata.videoTitle: Trampoline Basics for Snowboarders | Learn to Tramp Like a Pro – Ep. 1

metadata.text: The technique aims for a stable and balanced approach to the rail for consistent results.

metadata.fullText: This is normally happening because people are riding in and a two open up position or closing off too soon. Here I close off a little bit too soon and this is making it so my head's looking up and over my shoulder. Everything's connected and stiff and that's causing me to go and start preemptively rotating. Here we have a really sick front side 360 by Mons Royland. And I want you to pay attention to a couple things. First, look at how much bend he's keeping in his upper body, trying to keep his weight as stacked over top of his board as possible. Next, look at how patient he is closing off his front arm. He's keeping himself completely closed, and that's making it so he has a really large range of motion to play with. So when he pops off, he's leaving chest, not even rotated 90. This is a big jump and he's using a lot of upward momentum to get it inverted. But this is the same principles we want to be using. It's not about going and snapping hard. It's about snapping with a flexible enough range of motion that you can carry your momentum without going and overextending your upper body. So, the difference between me and my friend here is when I'm going and snapping my spin, I'm continuing that momentum all the way through where all of his power is being used to push upwards. So, I still have a bit of rotation of the tank and I'm going continue that rotation right there off the lip. See how my front arm is now pulling? My chest is leading. My hips are following instead of being in this straight position. One other major thing you're going to notice here is the hinge in my upper body is way more pronounced.
metadata.text: **Maintain a flexible, hinged upper body and patient arm closure to maximize your rotation's range of motion and carry momentum off the lip, rather than preemptively rotating or extending stiffly.**

metadata.fullText: If we jump into a board slide set over our heels, we're going to fall backwards. So that's why we really want to exaggerate pulling that upper body forward. So I want you to try get that range of motion, add a little bit more bend, add a little more more upper body forward than you expect, trying to keep your chest in line with your knees. And from there, you can go and counter rotate through. Now let's talk a little bit of a counter rotation because this is what really gets a lot of people because it's the trick itself. So, there's a couple ways you can do counter rotation. First, you can start with your upper body twisted and just let your legs follow. Uh, that's not too ideal, though, because you're not using your pop, your range of motion. And if you have your upper body twisted, it's a lot harder to keep your weight set in that right position. So, what I recommend practicing is lining up your pop with your counter rotation. This does a couple of things. By going and lining up when you're popping with your counter rotation, it's going to give you more lift. It's going to keep you more squared, what's letting you get a cleaner line off the jump. And then it's also going to let you go and pull your arms back. So, that's a very important part on every backside board slide is making sure as you pop up, you're counter rotating, pulling your arms this way. If you land with your arms like this, it's easy to pull it back to regular. But if you land with your arms in a neutral position or closed off, it's going to be very incredibly hard to pull it back. So, how do we want to train this? How much do we want to rep it? The answer is you don't need to train it too much. just a little bit a few times a week will really help. So when you're training your backside board slide, go add more bend to your legs.
metadata.text: To land a backside board slide, exaggerate leaning your upper body forward over your knees and counter-rotate your arms as you pop, lining up your pop with your counter-rotation for more lift and a cleaner finish.

metadata.text: Maintain a strong, centered body position with minimal movement, extending through your tail for powerful, controlled pops off side hits.

metadata.text: Wax your new snowboard with multiple coats before riding to protect the base and extend its lifespan.

metadata.text: Maintaining a flatter base before takeoff prevents unintentional edge catches and improves spin initiation.

metadata.text: Keep arms down below your head during spins and pop up, shifty, then pull back for shifty maneuvers to maintain control during tricks.

And then I keep the tightness more tight on the exterior to make up for it. A really important thing I note for this is I never can get my boots tight enough just when I'm putting them on. I generally have a free run system where I'll do one run with warm-up where my boots are a little bit looser, tighten them a bit, I do another run, tighten them a bit, and then my third run, I get them to the maximum tightness because I find if I just try to go straight to getting them as tight as possible, my feet just completely fall asleep. And that brings me into my last tip. Don't wear your boots too much.

metadata.fullText: So, if you're tall and straight on a snowboard, you're completely straining the body. But as you add bend to your legs, you don't want to keep your upper body straight like this. This isn't a strong position. This isn't balanced because it's keeping my weight too set over my flats of my feet. So, as you go and squat down, instead of trying to keep your back straight, pushing your hips out like this, that's going to make it so if you go too far, you're going to step back. Instead, we need to let our upper body come forward in correlation to our legs going down. So, it looks something like this. I find my neutral stack position and then the more bend I have the more my upper body comes down in correlation. A good way to put this is like chest over knees and then if your chest starts getting like two over knees that's no good because that's the biggest mistake people make while trying to maintain this position and that's letting their upper body come forward non-correlation. The difference is between trying to squat a squat lack and trying to go and touch your toes. As soon as you go and break your hips and reach into this touch toe position, your back's going to be compromised. You're going to be weak and you're not going to be able to put power through your motions. So, I want you to just go and practice getting in a stack position and feeling out your range of motion.

metadata.fullText: Whenever you do something like a wild cat, you want to shoot your hips forward and have your chest come up. And also look at his head positioning. A big misconception people have for wild cats is that you want to throw down towards your tail. But what you're actually trying to do here is jam the hips forward. And as you jam the hips forward, lift that chest up while keeping your neck connected because that's going to make it so you can naturally come in. But if you come and crunch yourself and have this neck crunch, it's going to make you weak. So if you're trying to do a wild cat, this is the best way to learn. Coming up patient on that takeoff, kicky takeoff, push your hips through, think you're trying to hip check the sky while keeping your core aligned and keeping your chest tall. You do that and you keep your head in a calm position, you're going to go and get to your feet.
metadata.text: For a wild cat, jam your hips forward and lift your chest while keeping your head connected to your shoulder, avoiding a neck crunch.

metadata.fullText: So, sure, your spot goes and starts at the end of a rail, but as you travel past it, your vision continues going downhill, just like you're riding. So, you start with your vision at the end of a rail, but it continues through. And this is going to let you see the landing, be completely in control, and that's going to let you have so much more power and finesse exiting any rail feature. When spinning a front side 360, it's really important to wait to grab.
metadata.text: **Look through the end of the rail, not just at it, to maintain control and power through your exit.**
metadata.videoTitle: 10 Park Tips Every Snowboarder Should Know!

metadata.text: Pop fully before grabbing to maintain rotation and control while avoiding ollies onto rails to lessen impact.
metadata.videoTitle: 10 Park Tips Every Snowboarder Should Know!

metadata.fullText: Popping and generating height off of side hits isn't about popping up and lifting your legs. Instead, it's about pushing into the ground and trying to maximize the time your board is making contact with the snow. And we do this by trying to mold our board around the feature. If it's bumpy, if it's kicky, we're trying to just push our board in and try to mold it through. Think about like having a little bit of plaster scene and trying to like jam it into a corner. You're like jamming it and molding it to that corner. Same thing we're trying to do with our snowboards.
metadata.text: To pop and gain height off side hits, push your board into the snow and mold it to the feature's contours to maximize contact time, rather than just lifting your legs.
metadata.videoTitle: Side-Hits Explained

metadata.fullText: And one of them always needs to be your takeoff. If you go and overthink what you don't want to be doing, that's exactly what your body's going to do.
metadata.text: **Focus on what you *want* to do at takeoff, not what you want to avoid, to ensure your body executes the desired action.**

metadata.fullText: But there's a few things we really need to avoid for this. Here, we can see that my student is going and closing off his upper body right away. So he's on his heel edge closing his upper body and trying to hold this position for a long time. But this is what we call a compromised position and it's going to make you want to lean more and more back towards that heel edge. So by the time he goes and gets to the lip and starts snapping, he's having his weight set all the way over his heels.
metadata.text: **Avoid closing off your upper body on the heel edge, as this leads to being too far back on your heels at the lip and hinders your snap.**
metadata.videoTitle: How To Fix Your Frontside 180s

metadata.text: Apply pressure to the balls of your feet for better control and responsiveness during quick movements.

metadata.text: Generate powerful takeoffs by shifting your weight back to your rear hip and simultaneously pulling your upper body forward, pivoting your rotation off the tail.

metadata.text: Employ a controlled leg pop for a cleaner and more fluid backside 360 spin.
metadata.videoTitle: Why Your Backside 360s Are Harder Then They Need To Be

metadata.fullText: You can go and get plenty of power just by maintaining strong legs and keeping your board in contact with the snow will give you plenty of power. And this is called coasting. But important thing when you're coasting is that you don't let your legs come down and squat because that's going to absorb the takeoff. So, you don't need to pop up a jump, but you do need to keep your legs strong and make sure that takeoff doesn't buck you. Every time you do a spin on a snowboard, you want to finish it with counter rotation. To do this, we lead a little bit with our upper body and counter rotate. And this lets us go and get max control, max power, and get that little bit of finesse. If you go and rotate all at once, don't lead with your upper body. You're going to land all at once, and it's going to remove any ability for finesse. So lead with your upper body and finish every spin of counter rotation because it slows down your maximum rotation velocity, gives you that micro control, and it makes coming into the landing so much easier and so much safer. This one trick is going to make your front side in runs so much easier. A lot of people when doing the front side spins are coming in from this tall position, relying on leaning, and then trying to shift down into their wound up position. But this is making it so they have to go and change body positions on the in run. What you actually want to do is preemptively set your upper body into your heel edge position. So that way you don't need to go and shift your balance points and instead you can just shift from toe edge to heel edge. By adding this little bit of bend in your legs on the in run of the jump, you'll be able to go and transition to your heel edge smoother.

metadata.fullText: Well, a front side 360 doesn't take much rotational power because you can finish it with counter rotation. If you don't have any rotational power coming off the lip, you're basically taking off with your chest 90 board straight and that's going to make you need to use counter rotation right away to try to get it around. When you use counter rotation this instantly, it's going to elongate you, make it so your spots no longer working, your arms being closed off, just a really uncomfortable situation.

metadata.fullText: This is because when you're jumping, it's really important to make sure you're leaving off the tail of your snowboard. But then, in order to compensate for this, I now go and pull my upper body forward towards the nose of my snowboard to compensate. And this is what pulls me naturally into the landing of the jump. So, that's how jumping works. It starts by being sunk up towards your back foot. And then as you lift off, you pull your upper body forward to compensate. So it's a rocking fluent motion, not some rigid double leg extension trying to jump up like you would for a box jump. Instead, it's flowing through. And yes, I'm still pushing with both my legs here, but I'm staggering them. Look at the bend in my front leg and my back leg. See how my front leg is more extended than my back leg here. And as that happens, I'm shifting my upper body forward, getting it over the nose. And this is a flexible motion. The steeper the jump, the more I'll need to pull my upper body forward in order to compensate for the angle and to meet up with the landing. Where if it's something like a roller, you don't need to do this nearly as much. But it's this rocking from the back foot up to the front foot that's maximizing the use of a snowboard, maximizing the range of motion of the body, letting me get maximum pop. And now let's talk about opening up that upper body. So, it's true if your upper body is too open when jumping, it's going to lead to some bad things. And the main thing is your board will try to sync up with your upper body as you leave the lip. So, watch here.

metadata.fullText: This is why he's riding so stiff and so uncontrolled and he's having a hard time getting that bend in his legs. Moving on to freestyle. I really want to showcase these positions by this ollie. This ollie, you'll notice, is very subtle, but it still gets a lot of power. And that's because I'm doing a couple of things. As I go and do this ollie, instead of doing a aggressive back and forth motion, instead I just have my weight set over that back leg, upper body pulled forward. This is increasing my range of motion, increasing my balance, letting me get away with this chest open position. So as I go and pop up, alls I need to do is extend both legs. The reason why people have so much difficulty with always in jumping is because if your legs are completely centered, as you go to jump up, both legs are going to leave at the same time. So if you try to get more range of motion, it's going to extend your upper body out of this nice hinge forward position. But because I have my weight shifted over the back foot as I go and pop up, I'm naturally getting that stagger and the pop, making it so I don't need to do any complex back and forth motion. Instead, my upper body keeps the same angle, my hips keep the same position, and my upper body being angled forward will naturally pull me down into the landing. Making the oi so much more simple than if you're trying to add all these back and forth straight-legged timing. This is as simple as I'm putting my weight into my back leg. Instead, he's just setting a pop with his upper body and head in the right spot. 360 becomes easy after that. This one's really cool. So he's coming to the railing, but he's alling off the toe edge. So hitting it heel side even though he's going toe edge. So, the reason why he can do this is because of his angle of approach. See how he's slightly angled towards the feature. Uh, sure, you could go on a heel edge, but when you're trying to gap this much and you're going off a heel edge, like we were talking about, you put more power into that, try to pop more, it's going to make you want to drift. So, what does he do to counter this? He sets his whole board on the angle towards the feature, then goes toe edge, and that goes and straightens out his angle onto the feature. And this is really cool. See how he's blunting the feature so much? This is because he's still having a lot of sideways momentum.
